1878424319|4.0|I was on something of a spiritual quest when I came across don Miguel Ruiz's book at a local store.  I looked inside the front flap and found 4 very simple statements, the truth of which were obvious: 1. Be impeccable with your word. 2. Don't take anything personally. 3. Don't make assumptions. 4. Always do your best.<br />They resonated with me: I'd been trying to live my life by those four concepts for years, but had never seen them stated so succinctly.  They were so plain to me that I actually considered not buying the book.<br />I'm glad I did, though, because I now have the opportunity to share its ideas with others.<br />The greatest misfortune of this book is that it's not really written for those who already understand what it's driving at; its congenial second-person style can come off a bit high-handed and superior at times, sort of an &quot;I've discovered this but you haven't&quot; tone.  If you live by the second agreement, this isn't a particular problem, though.<br />But as nice a read as it is for those who understand its concepts, I have to wonder if the tone isn't a bit off-putting to those who have yet to overcome the stumbling blocks of their own negative agreements. I tell people to pick up the book and read the inside front flap--if the text there resonates with them and they feel they can gain something from this book, they will.  If the agreements read like gibberish, or they're attempted to dismiss the book out of hand as yet another handful of spiritual SRIs for the spiritually depressed, I recommend they steer clear from it.<br />There are things in this book that can sting those who are unprepared for the spiritual path beyond its gates. For those, I recommend Robert Fisher's THE KNIGHT IN RUSTY ARMOR as a gentler introduction to what is, after all, a difficult but truly satisfying road to travel.
B00006C79E|1.0|Saint Etienne has finally made an album that falls completely on its face.  I read dozens of reviews claiming that \\"Finisterre\\" is somewhat of a throwback to their early 90s, sample heavy techno-dance-soul-pop work. While I would agree with that, I would also state that \\"Finisterre\\" pales in comparison to just about anything they've ever done. I was an avid fan of their previous work, most notably their striking debut, \\"Fox Base Alpha,\\" and their glorious, organic \\"full-band\\" album \\"Good Humor.\\" \\"Finisterre\\" turned out to be quite a let down for me, and that wouldn't matter so much had I not been bombarded with the deluge of critical praise that accompanied its release.    \\"Action\\" merely sounds like a rehashing of that early to mid-90s runway euro-disco-trash sound, coming off like a self-parody of their lesser tunes of that era. Puzzlingly, this retro theme pops up in several songs. Saint Etienne has made a habit of keeping up with trends and giving them their own unique twist, but here they've got what seem like obligatory yet uninspired, early 80s techo-pop throwbacks with \\"Amateur\\" and \\"B92,\\" perhaps to placate those who've immersed themselves in today's obsession with new wave; nice analog synths, but the songs leave little to hold on to. There are also a few seriously rambling, pointless instrumentals, the worst offender being \\"Language Lab.\\" And the only really catchy melody on the whole album is in the obnoxious, cloying \\"Soft Like Me,\\" featuring some of the most cringe-inducing, clich√©-ridden rapping imaginable (courtesy of female Brit-rapper Wildflower), sounding - alarmingly - quite like the Spice Girls (!).  The chorus, sung by Cracknell, is so annoyingly catchy that any laundry detergent company would be FOOLISH *not* to use this for a commercial jingle.  The remainder of the record is pretty forgettable. The title track is nice, but nothing extraordinary.    So, what we have here is a once-talented band running on empty, churning out an album full offorgettable fluff and filler. I hate to sound snobby, but maybe it's time to bid St. Etienne adieu.

B00003CXPJ|4.0|If the movies are to be believed, stupid people have insights into society that the rest of us just aren't privy to. Films such as DUMB &amp; DUMBER, DUDE, WHERE'S MY CAR?, BEAVIS AND BUTTHEAD DO AMERICA, and the Bill &amp; Ted series show us people who are intellectually ill-equipped to deal with society, yet somehow, in their ignorance and naivete, end up on top of the heap.<br />Derek Zoolander (Ben Stiller) starts out on top of the heap: he's the most successful male model in America, but his career is on the wane, being quickly eclipsed by upstart model Hansel (Owen Wilson). When a tragic gasoline-fight accident kills Derek's three roommates, he decides the time has come to retire.<br />This leads directly into the film's over-the-top MANCHURIAN-CANDIDATE-style political assassination plot, but the real fun here is in the characters rather than the story.<br />As the story unfolds, characters who were sold to us as stupid turn out to have a certain savvy and a flair for living that transcends intelligence, which is really the message of all the films in this &quot;genre:&quot; ignorance is indeed bliss, and what's important is knowing that you have a place in the world even if you don't understand what it is.<br />Derek's triumph is strange and appropriate to the film, and we all get an opportunity to wonder why people are so quick to judge; just because you can't see or comprehend someone's finest talent, that doesn't mean it doesn't exist.<br />An enjoyable effort from Ben Stiller (who also directed), but certainly not for everyone--if, for you, stupid characters make for a stupid movie, this is one you should pass on. If you're interested in the keen insight into society that the eyes of those less intellectually-gifted can bring, this one stands tall in the chain of films that carry that message.  It's certainly no BEING THERE, but it's fun, and, if nothing else, it will make you think about not being able to think.

B00006M183|4.0|There has been plenty for Pearl Jam to write songs about since their 2000 release &quot;Binaural&quot;.  Commentary on the questionable Bush presidency, September 11, and losing 9 fans at a concert in Roskilde are all easily recognizable in Eddie Vedder's lyrics throughout &quot;Riot Act&quot;.  <br />However, what might be an anticipated downer of an album is actually infused with plenty of things to smile about.  Not only does the band share songwriting responsibilities once again, including a grinding guitar fest from drummer Matt Cameron called &quot;You Are&quot;,  but they've continued to expand their lineup, adding keyboards to some tracks from Vedder's island pal Boom Gaspar.<br />Perhaps more surprising is that while many of the 15 tracks feature heavy riffs reminscient of the start of 1994's &quot;Vitalogy&quot;, the lyrics somehow find a glimmer of hope amidst all of the turmoil that the band sees in their collective worlds.  Not only does the word &quot;love&quot; appear 20 times in the lyric booklet, but Vedder shows the wisdom that comes with age and rock and roll longevity with lines like &quot;No matter how cold the winter / there's a springtime ahead.&quot;  Perhaps in another 10 years we'll be hearing similar things from Staind or Creed.  I for one won't hold my breath.<br />One note: Republicans might wanna skip this album and buy the new Christina Aguilera instead.  Something tells me you'd be happier that way.

B00005YXZH|4.0|\\"Yankee Hotel Foxtrot\\" is like nothing else in the Wilco catalog to date, which doesn't bother me because I'm not much of a fan of the rest of their work. What I like about this album is its attempt to delve into the world of art rock. (Indeed, their previous record label turned down the record for its experimental edge, which wasn't thought to be commercial enough.) I applaud Wilco for trying to bring something different to a large audience in this day and age. They do this with a variety of computer effects, jangling pianos, and background noises that weave in and out of some of the songs. Sometimes it works, and sometimes it doesn't. The opening track, \\"I Am Trying to Break Your Heart,\\" flaunts its sounds overmuch during a rather slight song that goes on too long, instead of concisely and seamlessly integrating them the way the Beatles used to do. Nevertheless, it is refreshing to hear some different sounds now and then over the usual rock band stuff. Even a slightly unusual tweak in the mixing, such as the lush, pronounced guitar sound that is featured in \\"I'm the Man Who loves You,\\" is a breath of fresh air. I could have used fewer fuzzy distorted sounds, which aren't that rare these days, and a few more rich backing tracks, without such a thin underlying sound (acoustic guitars, drums, ho hum. How about some organs or flutes or something...?) Fans of this album will also want to check out the work of a band called Shivaree, who mix a variety of sounds in the backgrounds of their songs too.
B00003CWTI|3.0|I saw \\"Magnolia\\" in the theatre in January, 2000. While I wasn't wetting my pants over the film as many critics were, I liked it enough to buy the DVD later that summer. Now that I've given it a recent viewing, I've concluded that \\"Magnolia\\" ranks up there with \\"Doctor Zhivago,\\" \\"The Piano,\\" and \\"Gladiator\\" as one of the most overrated films to hit the silver screen. There's as much to admire as there is to pick at, and while \\"Magnolia\\" has great performances and a promising premise, it's a strange step backward for the director who gave us the vastly superior \\"Boogie Nights.\\" To summarize, 11 people in southern California are somehow united through circumstance, tragedy, or bloodlines. None of the characters are very likeable, and a handful of them are so stupid or immersed in their own angst, you pray they get hit by a lightening bolt to put them out of their misery. The Black characters, all background roles, offer little more than crass stereotypes: the fat and boisterous ghetto woman, the preteen pickpocketing \\"rapper,\\" and the timid journalist who gets disrespected by a smug, self-help guru (Tom Cruise). Some scenes require you to suspend disbelief to digest fully. How that cop (Reilly) was able to befriend and romance that train wreck of a drug addict without so much as suspecting her condition is beyond me, and for that reason, that subplot failed. And while Paul Thomas Anderson is a gifted and articulate screenwriter, he must have skipped the class in film school that taught dramatic subtlety. The score, while lush and beautiful, gets overempowering for a huge portion of the movie as it tries to underscore the film's dramatic tension. Completely unnecessary. Hitchcock will tell you that less is often more. And the film's bizarre final scene, which aimed to \\"tie up everything together,\\" was unacceptable and showed that Anderson failed to come up with a way to coherently end the film. And the length? I've seen three hour movies that dragged at a worse pace, but a film like \\"Magnolia\\" could have been trimmed by at least one hour.<br />You'd think that by reading the above, I would despise \\"Magnolia.\\" Quite the contrary. While there are good performances and intriguing moments, I don't think it deserves to be put on such a high pedestal. For that reason, its considerable warts earn the film a mere B- in my school of cinema.ut a film like \\"Magnolia\\" could have been trimmed by at least one hour. <br />You'd think that by reading the above, I would despise \\"Magnolia.\\" Quite the contrary. B00003CXXJ|3.0|Based on William Steig's bizzare backwards fairy tale, DreamWork's SHREK has fantastic animation, great voice casting and infamous \\"irreverent\\" humor. An ogre and a donkey rescuing a princess for an under-endowed King. How cleverly post-modern. Ha and indeed ha. Yes, it's a worldwide cartoon phenomenon or something like that. Now don't get me wrong, I like the recent movies like this one that trade traditional cute jokes for movie lampooning and irreverent gags, but I find it hard to avoid the fact that this \\"hilarious\\" comedy is somewhat overrated. Shrek (Mike Myers) and Donkey (Eddie Murphy) are a good odd-couple and there are some great jabs at Disney throughout the film's running time. But fart gags and weird humor aside, it's not as clever as it thinks it is. There are some fantastically funny moments in the film, especially the gingerbread man sequence and lines like \\"In the morning, i'm making waffles!\\" And the escape from the dragon's castle is a tour-de-force of fantastic animation and strange gags. However it's far more funnier if you take it as the sum of its parts rather than the movie as a whole. It may sound like just knocking success, but if you actually sit back and watch it, well, it really depends on if you want to sit through a cartoon with gross-out humour and fart gags. From a technical standpoint, the CGI photo-realistic water and fur simulation is brilliant. Since the success of TOY STORY, computer-generated cartoons have come a long way and it's impossible to deny that the CG is impressive. But then, so was the CG in Godzilla (Lesson: Impressive effects do not a good movie make). Watching SHREK in comparison to Pixar's competition MONSTERS INC, the latter is a more clever premise. Shrek gets 5 stars for animation, but it's a 3 star movie for laughs. the DVD extras are impressive though, with Commentaries, mock interviews, 'making of' docos and trailers.

B00006NSGX|3.0|As a long-time fan of Clapton, I was pleasantly surprised that this effort meets my expectations. The output comprises excellent musicianship, and a loose feel. While not quite smokey blues, it has some funky, inspired moments. It's enhanced by the occasional fluffed note from Clapton -- he's taking a few chances, even in no one else is.<br />Highlights include a lively acoustic Key To The Highway, a joyful My Father's Eyes, a blustering River Of Tears and a manic She's Gone. Even tired favourites like Wonderful Tonight have a new twist. The multi-soloist HYELAW is another refreshing change from the plain blues-rock version. <br />The sound is first class, but on hearing the CD several times I've realised there are some serious flaws too.<br />1. The band is too slick, and lacks any \\"teen spirit\\". Granted Clapton is not a spring chicken, but the energy and passion of younger bands is sorely lacking, especially in the back up musicians. It would be better to have younger players with some spark rather than technically perfect oldies. His band add nothing, which probably explains why the best tracks like Key To The Highway, She's Gone feature EC more prominently.<br />2. There's a commercial over-reliance on standards such as Sunshine of Your Love and Cocaine. I have just heard them too many times, and it gets boring for long-time fans. More from Reptile or Pilgrim would have been appreciated. Or classic but forgotten tracks like Tales of Brave Ulysees, WDLGTBSS, Easy Now, The Core, Keep on Growin' etc etc (there are so many).<br />This may not be an album for those looking for non-stop guitar fireworks, but Clapton's guitar pyrotechnics always worked better for being spare. (Cream fans should listen again to the dreary Live Cream 2 before they react!). Fans of Unplugged Clapton should love this too. Dedicated fans probably have too much of this already.<br />Nevertheless, his best official live recording since the 70s.

B00006M183|4.0|Pearl Jam's most recent effort \\"Riot Act\\" continues to show why the boys from Seattle are truly one of the greatest bands of all-time.  Pearl Jam has demonstrated its lizard like transformation over the past ten years by continually reinventing themselves.<BR> Most casual fans of Pearl Jam think back to the early 90's when the band was considered by many to a be a grunge band similar to Nirvana (although true fans of the band will argue that Pearl Jam has always been a pure rock band and never grunge).  It is true that the albums \\"Ten\\" and \\"Vs\\" certainly have the aura of being in the grunge category.<BR> However with the death of Kurt Kobain in 1994, the grunge scene began to rapidly die off.  Pearl Jam realized this well in advance and following their third album \\"Vitalogy,\\" they made an almost unprecedented transformation.<BR> Their fourth album \\"No Code\\" truly showed the true array of talent that exists within this group.  Soft and almost hypnotic ballads intertwined with the classic hard rock made for an incredible record.  The same can be said for \\"Yield\\" and \\"Binaural.\\"  Pearl Jam had shown its ability to adapt over time.<BR> The 7th album \\"Riot Act\\" continues to show the personality of the new Pearl Jam.  Some of the lyrics are clearly post September 11th, such as in \\"Love Boat Captain\\" or \\"I Am Mine.\\"  Ed Vedder and the boys truly have a wonderful album that has a nice variety of soft and hard rock.  This is an album that proves Pearl Jam is capable of sustaining themselves through the test of time.  There is no arguing that this might be the best band in the last two decades.
B00006M183|4.0|I've never balked at any musician who follow their hearts.  Pearl Jam's progression and direction may not please everyone and their later releases may not have the angst and aggression of &quot;10&quot;, but people grow and Eddie and company have matured into brilliant (at times understated), craftsmen.  I applaud the organic nature of their new work.  It is reminiscent of the rock and roll roots they sprung from (Neil Young, The Band, et al.) You can FEEL these guys and you KNOW they can play the hell out of their instruments...a breath of fresh air.
B00006NSGX|3.0|I was eagerly anticipating this new 2 cd live set from Eric Clapton. This 2 disk set contains 19 songs from his 2001 tour (the DVD version contains 1 extra song).  When I noticed his backing band contained such capable musicians as drummer Steve Gadd, and keyboardists Billy Preston and David Sancious I expected a great set.  Perhaps since Clapton is such a fine musician my expectations exceeded the results. However this set is the weakest live recording he has released.  The majority of the first disk he plays acoustic guitar albeit expertly probably in an effort to help duplicate the success of his &quot;Unplugged&quot; disk.  The best acoustic cut and probably the best cut on the set is the version of &quot;Bell Bottom Blues&quot;.  The problem with the set is that Clapton seems to have adapted the stance of one of his heroes J.J. Cale.  The set is too laid back!  The songs seem for the most part uninspired.  The older songs have been played countless times and already exist in better live versions.  The majority of the newer songs especially those from his &quot;Pilgrim&quot; disk are just plain weak.  Songs such as &quot;Badge&quot; contain truncated guitar solos in favor of annoying synthesizer noodling.  The least he could have done was include a piano or B-3 organ solo instead those annoying synthesizers. The disks are about an hour each so more songs could have been included on the set.  In addition, the set would have been more interesting if Clapton included some older rarely played numbers or some blues covers not included on his previous albums.  If you compare this set to the &quot;Crossroads 2&quot; set Clapton's solos in songs such as &quot;Badge&quot;, &quot;Have You Ever Loved A Woman&quot;, or &quot;Driftin' Blues&quot; from that set beat anything on this set hands down! Hopefully Clapton will return to his blues roots for his next set, until then this set is for diehards only.

0345404475|4.0|The Science Fiction novel \\"Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?\\" by Philip K. Dick tells the story of Rick Deckart, a bounty hunter from San Fransisco in the year of 1992, which is in the future. His job is to \\"retire\\", means kill, humanoid robots who have escaped from their masters.<br />One of the main aspects the novel points out is the definition of life and therefore the evaluation of human and artificial life. In order to maintain the tension, the author purposly adds either human characteristics to the behavior of androids or the other way around. This keeps the reader guessing about the real identity of the persons in the novel (human or android?) and questions the low value of artificial life.<br />Empathy plays an important role in the topic. This so-called human characteristic is the key to distinguish androids from humans and makes it possible for the bounty hunters to detect androids. But in the course of the novel it becomes more and more clear to the reader that there is a lot more to genuine life than empathy.<br />Another aspect in the novel is the animal cult. Because of the harming dust, which has lead to the decrease and even extinction of animal species, animals have become a status symbol in society. As the example of androids, there are also artificial animals, which resemble the genuine animals astonishly. This aspect has the function of mirroring the situation between humans and androids.<br />Philip K. Dick has risen a very topical question, even though he wrote the book in 1968. Genetic engineering has become an important question that keeps us questioning about the definition and value of the life.<br />The story of the novel is very interesting and once you start reading, it is hard to put it away. What I personally disliked was the end of the novel. It was very confusing and did not reach me at all. For me, the story ended abruptly did not seem as precisly structured as it was in the rest of the book. Still, I would definitely recommend reading the book instead of watching the movie \\"Blade Runner\\".the book instead of watching the movie \\"Blade Runner\\".
6304806426|4.0|I just want to make a comment on the picture quality of the DVD as the 5/5 picture quality rating is misleading. I watched it in a theatre and was impressed with the quality of the film in every aspect. <br />The DVD is in widescreen letterbox format -- standard 4:3 screen with top and bottom chopped off to achieve 16:9. The resolution and details really suffer compared with anamorphic DVDs (a good reference is The Fifth Element, superbit version). The picture noise and artifacts are apparent through out the scenes, especially if you watch it on a big screen HDTV, though overall color reproduction is close to the film. The DD 5.1 sound is excellent -- I'd rather watch the DVD with my eyes closed, as the resolution of my mind is almost infinite (though not very accurate. The original theatrical experience helped :) <br />This film deserves a DVD re-release with better picture encoding/compression, which I hear is coming &quot;Real Soon Now&quot;.

0553277472|5.0|I finally read 'Zen', one of those books that nags at you for years before you've even read it. Every copy I've ever run across is dog-eared, warped from water and tinged brown from time and the smoke from fire places and camp fires. Here is my take: Pirsig's entire \\"inquiry into value\\" (a subject which he seems to take too far, and no wonder he goes a bit nutty trying to subdivide and take the subject to its logical end, when there is no logical end, because it is largely subjective in my opinion)was less important to me than his stark look at his own weaknesses and eventual madness, which he recovers from by being, at least in part, a different person. That he does this gradually, teasing us with glimpses through the looking glass to the thoughts and doings of 'Phaedrus', is gripping. I empathized with Pirsig's railings against the system, although his intellecutal arrogance perhaps stopped me short of complete sympathy. But I really admired him for facing himself this way - it is harrowing and kind of beautiful - and his realization in the end, when for a crucial moment he gets out of his head and sees what has been before him the whole time - really gave me the shivers. This human oddyssey, of a man too intelligent for his own good, is what I think makes 'Zen' an extraordinary, special book that stands on its own and will for many decades to come.

However, this very reason may make the book appealing to older readers, as so many fantasy novels focus on a youthful hero.<br />Robin Hobb's matured writing style is reflected in the matured characters and broader range of human emotions. This is a complex book character-wise, although the story is easy to follow.<br />As with all of Hobb's series, this one starts slow, allowing us to know our main characters before thrusting them into the action. However, it is never dull as so many introductions can be. Words and events are used judiciously.<br />I liked the underlying premise of this particular book, which seemed to be that beasts can be more noble than humans. This is shown both in the character of Nighteyes, Tom's wolf companion, and his distaste for unnecessary killing, as well as in the villain's disregard for the well-being of animals. I cannot say much more without giving away the plot, which has many surprises. These surprises are well set up in the beginning of the book, without giving away what they are. 0393317552|5.0|The book is the result of an attempt to explain why some civilizations (civilization is definitely not the correct word to use here. I am using it for lack of a better term. \\"A region occupied by a homogeneous ethnic group\\" is what I believe the author is basing his arguments on) came to evolve faster than others. The book consists of three parts; the first in posing the question, the second in developing theories as of why differences in speed of advancements in different civilizations occur, and lastly in applying the author's theories to different continents.<br />The author attributes differences in available natural resources at the time of exploitation as reasons of disparities in speed of development. A typical argument of his would evolve as such (excerpt from chap. 9): \\"How can we explain the concentration of the Ancient Fourteen [domesticated animals] in Eurasia? ... One reason is simple. Eurasia has the largest number of big terrestrial wild animal species, whether or not ancestral to a domesticated species. Table x.x shows that Eurasia has the most candidates ... [Table x.x contains 1) candidates and 2) percentage of candidates actually domesticated] ... But why were Eurasia's horses domesticated but not Africa's Zebras? ... Efforts at domestication went as far as hitching Zebras to carts: they were tried out as draft animals in 19C Africa, and the eccentric Lord Walter Rothschild drove through the streets of London in a carriage by zebras. Alas, zebras become impossible dangerous as they grow older. Zebras have the unpleasant habit of biting a person and not letting go. They thereby injure even more American zookeepers each year than do tigers! ...\\"<br />Diamond evidently adopts a divide-and-conquer strategy in his arguments. A quick, immediately palpable reason succeeds the initial question he poses, followed by an abundance of physiological and/or physical evidence. From the evidence yet another set of questions arise, which are in turn answered withmore ample evidence, often times supplemented with historical annectdotes.<br />Diamond's evolutionary/physiological/physical approach is not without precedents. The historian Ferdiand Braudel, as well as biologist Cavalli-Sforza for example used similiar arguments in their numerous publications. However none of their publications are as thorough in evidence and at the same time as accessible as this book. It was an enjoyable, and in a sense, relaxing read.<br />With what little knowledge I have, I gather that evolutionary theories are in (for every social phoenomenon there seems to be an associated evolutionary theoretic explanation nowadays). There will be other ways in the future to explain the very same question Diamond attempted to tackle, but till then there will be more than enough time for Diamond's \\"historical science\\" (as he puts it) to evolve.

It is only until Susie can let earth go that they will be able to do that.

0140177396|4.0|&quot;I seen hunderds [sp] of men come by on the road an' on the ranches, with their bindles on their back an' that same damn thing in their heads. They're all the time talkin' about it, but it's jus' in their head.\\" <br />Lennie and George are two laborers who work along the Californian ranches. They live their lives traveling to find work whenever and where they can. Lennie is a rather large man with enough strength to do hard work.  Unfortunately, Lennie has a mental disability, denying him the privilege of having a higher intelligence than that of a child.  George is Lennie's caretaker and best friend.  George's characteristics are opposite of Lennie.  He is intelligent and small.  Like many laborers during that time, Lennie and George dream of owning their own piece of land.  They plan to live life without a boss and make their own decisions.  Lennie and George know this dream can come true, but a set of unfortunate events, characters, and Lennie's attraction to trouble begin to alter their dreams and future plans. <BR> Throughout the novel, Of Mice and Men, Steinbeck is able to depict many themes.  The themes that are found include understanding disabilities, racism, loneliness, and segregation.  Characters that are encountered in Of Mice and Men are creatively used as symbols to describe the themes.  <BR> I recommend this book to anyone who enjoys novels that provide good meaning and insight. B0000797IO|4.0|...<br />Aniston plays Justine Last, a clerk at a discount store, whose life is the picture of tedium. Justine has spent her life in this small Texas town, avoiding college for fear that it would cost her her husband working at the same dreary job for years... The two enter into an elicit affair that stretches the boundaries of what Justine thought her life was about and causes her to reevaluate everything she holds dear.<br />This movie works, but it's not on the strength of the writing...film bills itself as a comedy, but for the most part is far more dramatic. Most of the really funny moments all seem to come at the hands of Zooey Deschanel who plays a cynical worker at the department store who has fun with the public address system and with unsuspecting cosmetics customers.<br />Which brings us to where this movie does work -- the performances. Deschanel is great in her cynical voice, with impeccable comedic timing. Gyllenhall is also good as the young man who wants to be J.D. Salinger so badly he's already planning to disappear after writing one novel. Reilly, as Aniston's husband, takes a character that could very easily have been a stereotypical tank-top wearing, wife-beating husband and injects some real humanity. You get the impression that Phil Last is a man who genuinely cares about his wife and would do anything for her, he's just too stupid to realize there's a problem. Nelson, who's almost always good, compliments Reilly's bumbling good-hearted character well.<br />Aniston, however, really shines in this film. Her accent seems quite natural -- the only times it ever feels out of place is when you remind yourself how long she's played the spoiled rich girl on Thursday nights and compare the two voices. She is convincing as someone who has painted her entire life into a corner and doesn't know how to escape. Director Miguel Arteta uses a very understated style that works for the movie -- it's never too flashy, never too loud. The movie knows its pace and keeps it well. Only the script by Mike White keeps it from being a truly great work...<br />Although you can see the end of the movie coming a mile away, the performances of \\"The Good Girl\\" make it worth checking out. Perhaps for the first time in her career, Aniston has proven she can play a good deal more than this particular title would imply.keeps it well. Only the script by Mike White keeps it from being a truly great work...<br />Although you can see the end of the movie coming a mile away, the performances of \\"The Good Girl\\" make it worth checking out. Perhaps for the first time in her career, Aniston has proven she can play a good deal more than this particular title would imply.

0553381687|5.0|All the great epic fiction - be it LotR or WoT or Shannara or StarWars, or even the much praized Harry Potter - evolve around some unsuspecting village boy destined to overcome the ultimate super-villain (who had usually once been defeated but regained strength), and always our unsuspecting boy is guided by some wizened and powerful mentor, at least in the beginning: Frodo guided by Gandalf to destroy Sauron, Rand al'Thor guided by Moraine to face the Dark One, Skywalker guided by Kenobi to challenge the evil embodied by the Emperor and his right hand, the gruesome Darth Vader, or Harry Potter guided by Dumbledore on his way to battle Voldemort.<br />Not so with Ice and Fire. G.R.R. presents us with a multitude of deeply developed characters, non of them belonging to the group of unsuspecting village citizen. On the contrary, almost each of them is in his own way struggling for power, for himself, his beloved or any of purposes worth fighting for, driven by a variety of motives ranging from honor to greed, from revenge to desparation, employing methods as straightforward as warfare or as subtle as intrigue.<br />Heroism comes to these characters by nessecity of survival rather than impressed upon them by some greater cause or destiny, and it is far from being a guarantee to survive, either. All of this makes this epic so real, that you are reminded it is fiction only by the unfamiliar geografy of the world and - well - some sparsely but effectfully deployed mystery, such as bits and pieces of magic, some curious disbalance in the seasons, and an ominious but growing threat from the far north.<br />If you want to read something where you really could imagine yourself in the midst of it, this series is the right thing for you. Beside all things I said so far, it should be mentioned that between the covers of this books is packed the densest suspense, and a lot of surprises, not all of them pleasant.
6304806418|1.0|So much to learn from this movie:<BR>(1) The device of the 'generic antagonist' can never work. Banderas tries really hard. It's just silly and distracting at first, but it ends up silly and unresolvable.<BR>(2) Never make a musical about electoral politics. It's as inspiring as a feature-length campaign ad.<BR>(3) Avoid showing every damn moment! Her rise, the best part of the movie, took an hour. Her elections took another hour! Her death took yet another hour! And it seemed like a lifetime!<BR>(4) The best singing on earth can't help a script that runs three times as long as it should, and which says nothing new after the first 30 minutes.<BR>(5) When writing musicals, less is more. Throw away everything repetitive, everything trivial: songs, music, lyrics, ideas, set pieces ... there were moments at the beginning where I thought the creators had some sense of this. And then they just went on some sort of mindless drunken bender, echoing themselves ad nauseum.<BR>Please -- Hollywood -- Webber -- please try to value the time of the little people! We don't have any true free time! Because there's so much junk to consume!
0553381709|5.0|I will refrain from getting into judgement whether Storm is better as Game or Clash, but it definitely upholds the standards set by G.R.R.<BR>The most remarkable feature of this epic fantasy saga, setting it apart from all others, is the absence of a quest. Also absent is a clear distinction between overwhelming good and overwhelming evil, though certainly some of the characters are more evil than others. What is unique for this series is the in-depth development of individual characters of all sides of the conflict(s). The characters which we learn most about are not nessecarily the greatest heros or greatest villains. Characters which we grew to dislike over the course of the first installments suddenly are given their own voices, calling for understanding, which we grow reluctant to withhold. For example, even if it would never cross our mind to forgive Jamie the Kingslayer for throwing little Bran out the window, we come to understand and respect certain aspects of his personality. <BR>What also sets this saga apart from all others is the complete unpredictability of the outcome. Even in the classic of all classics of the genre, the ultimate victory of good over evil is predictable from the very beginning, the only question remaining how it will be brought about. In ASoIaF we don't even know the ultimate goal, let alone whether it will be achieved or not (I would not even be surprised finding myself surprised by the revelation that the feared Others aren't bad at all, but simply misunderstood champions of some uncomprehensible cause of greater good). G.R.R. keeps us suspended, secondguessing and tearing ourselves apart in awaiting the next sequel, making this the best fantasy series ever encountered.

We don't really get to learn about how the characters got into the army; who they interact well with; etc. Come to think of it, after all the complaints of Pearl Harbour and its run-on plot, this seemed like the most sufficient way to narrate the film. <br />Final Thoughts on Black Hawk Down <br />Josh Hartnett, Ewan McGregor, Tom Sizemore, Sam Shepherd and Ewen Bremner and some characters we can remember from Pearl Harbour fill the movies cast. Dialogue seemed to not matter in this one. <br />I finally saw a new release on the first day and would recommend this film to anyone who has a good stomach. Wait 30 minutes after eating to go in the water; wait 4 hours to watch this movie after eating dinner! <br />* The Mogue is what the two US forces called Mogadishu!
B000001ESF|5.0|I cannot stress getting this album enough. If you have any curiosity about Rush and aren't quite sure which album is a good one to start off with, this is the one. Many people tend to go with Moving Pictures(Rush's \\"Dark Side Of The Moon\\"), the only Rush album people think is worth owning which is complete and utter B.S. The song 2112 is worth the price alone. It may not be Rush's best song in many peoples' ears, but it's certainly the best piece of music by them that I've ever heard. And I own the Rush catalog. The biggest problem Rush haters have with the band is the vocals. Well, the vocals are in full swing here. This is the wildest Geddy Lee would ever get with his singing(screaming). The title track on full volume beats any modern metal band in it's intensity(and this is a mid seventies album by a band not even considered heavy metal!). Yeah, some consider it kind of corny lyrically, but scrooooo it. The epic sci-fi/fantasy concept wasn't stale yet in the mid seventies, it certainly is now with about six billion metal bands doing it. If you ask me, this is the best introduction you could have to Rush instead of Moving Pictures which seems to be the norm. I'm not ripping on Moving Pictures, that album is amazing, but there's a lot more to Rush than Tom Sawyer.

I loved former movie but I believe this series is even better. <br />The first episode dealt with the intense training that Easy Company went through in Georgia. They were pioneers in Airborne (Parachutists) warfare. Hanks and Spielberg <BR>deliberately did not go after the big name Hollywood stars. The best known actor appears in the first episode as the hated Captain Herbert Sobel as portrayed by David Schwimmer from the \\"Friends\\" cast. Sobel was so mean that many of his trainees talked about killing him when they arrived in Europe. The training was not only physically exhausting but Sobel was a master of mind games. B000003TAR|4.0|First a confession: I was never a big Nirvana fan. While the band's music was fairly catchy, had a lot of emotion and was certainly better than that of bands like New Kids On The Block and Paula Abduhl, it was generally brought down by weak lyrical writing and Kurt Cobain's irritating voice (I know most will disagree with me here). <br />In 1993, the band released their follow up to the enormously popular Nevermind: In Utero, which was in a lot of ways a rougher, darker and more mature version of Nevermind. But did that necessarily make it the masterpiece Nevermind (in my humble opinion) wasn't? <br />The first thing you'll notice when listening to In Utero is that the production is a bit rougher than on Nevermind. The music still comes in crystal clear, and there's very little static or garbling. But the instruments sound a bit rougher this time around (sometimes I was left wondering whether or not the band ever rehearsed these songs), no doubt to reflect the darker atmosphere portrayed on the album. Kurt Cobain also sounds a lot less happy-go-lucky and more tortured than he did on Nevermind. The problem is that he simply wasn't a very good singer IMO (definitely not as good as people make him out to be). At times he sounds almost like an old woman, and other times he sounds a bit overly dramatic (in a forced way). <br />Contrary to what some may have led you to believe, In Utero does have its share of commercial leanings. Many songs like Rape Me and Serve The Servants have very pop-like beats and tempos, while there is a lot of that subtle acoustic work popular with both grunge and alternative bands. As a bonus, Nirvana throws a few country/southern rock influences into some of the songs here (such as the aforementioned Rape Me). On the other hand, there are those songs like Tourette's and Scentless Apprentice that are purposefully grating to the ears of the average listener, but for the most part, In Utero is a straight-up alternative rock album. Not a punk or heavy metal album. <br />Lyrical writing was never one of Nirvana's strong points, and In Utero is (for the most part) no exception. Every once in a while, the band will throw in some interesting and even somewhat philosophical lines (\\"I miss the comfort in being sad\\" - Frances Farmer Will Have Her Revenge On Seattle), but for the most part, the lyrical writing is very abstract and difficult for the average listener to understand. Perhaps this is intentional as Kurt probably wanted listeners to not only hear but FEEL what he was going through, but it really detracts from the band's creative potential (as, once again, they do have their occasional gems). <br />As usual, here's a rundown of each track: <br />1. Serve The Servants - In Utero gets off to a strong start with the sarcastic yet fun pop/rock track Serve The Servants. The album features an awesome acoustic riff backed by some truly meaningful and surprisingly well written lyrics (\\"All my life I wanted a father but instead I got a dad\\"), stating that if you have loving supportive parents, appreciate them (for I Kurt Cobain wish I had the same thing). Listen to the song's verse (\\"Serve The Servants... Oh no\\"). If Kurt's singing of it sounds familiar to you, it's just because so many alternative bands thereafter have imitated it. Definitely one of the album's best. <br />2. Scentless Apprentice - This was Nirvana's first attempt at a less commercial track. Unfortunately, for them, the riff has a fairly mainstream (at least by today's standards) sound to it, and the only real screaming is during the chorus. The song is basically several verses strung together with one giant guitar arpeggio following and then Kurt screaming \\"HEEEEEEEEEEYYYYYYYYYYY!!!! GO AWAY!!!!\\" The song succeeds in illustrating Kurt's suffering, and stands as one of the better tracks. <br />3. Heart Shaped Box - Probably the most mainstream song on the album, Heart Shaped Box is a song about how even though Kurt knows Courtney Love has treated him really badly, he still somehow feels this sense of love for her (I think at least a few of us can relate to that). Although Kurt's singing voice can be fairly irritating, the song's saved by its instrumental/lyrical emotion and powerful chorus. A very good track. <br />4. Rape Me - I remember first seeing this song being played on Saturday Night Live many years ago. It also got quite a bit of radio airplay where I live. As it is, Rape Me is an alternative track with a nice southern rock acoustic riff and silly but somewhat sensual lyrics (about social injustice). A very catchy if unspectacular song. <br />5. Frances Farmer Will Have Her Revenge On Seattle - A song how grating fame can really be. Kurt Cobain attempts a country-like voice here and somewhat succeeds. The riff is simple yet effective. But the chorus is rather grating thanks to the way it is literally whined towards the end. Another decent yet unspectacular track. <br />6. Dumb - One of my personal favorites, Dumb is another pop-like track with an all around catchy tone and even a nice cello in the background. I don't quite agree with Kurt Cobain's philosophy here (\\"I think I'm dumb. But I'm just happy\\"), but the fact that he had the guts to express it makes the song all the more worth listening to. A nice, less serious break from the sometimes overly dramatic music Nirvana and most other grunge/alternative bands were playing. <br />7. Very Ape - This song could almost be considered a foreshadowing of the release of Green Day's Dookie as it is a fast paced pop-punk track with a nice riff and good drumming. It's nothing to get excited about, but a fun song nonetheless. <br />8. Milk It - Another punk-pop track, albeit slower and heavier. Milk It has a good riff backed by (guess what?) more whining courtesy of Kurt Cobain. There are some fairly interesting lyrics here, and the drumming is rock solid. All around good track. <br />9. Pennyroyal Tea - A slow, dark anti-abortion track with some nice guitarwork and a lot of emotion. The chorus is a little annoying though. The Unplugged version is actually better. <br />10 - 11. Radio Friendly Unit Shifter/Tourette's - I'll just review these two songs in the same paragraph since they're basically just a bunch of guitar noise and screaming courtesy of Kurt and Company. No doubt, these \\"songs\\" were intended to scare off some mainstreamers and not much else. Still, they really show the pain Kurt Cobain went through, and definitely have their place on the album. <br />12. All Apologies - The final track, and a good one at that. All Apologies is basically Kurt's suicide song, describing what he's been through, and why he must leave this world for good. At the end he quotes John Lennon (\\"All in all is all we are\\") as the finishing touch to this moving track. Definitely worth listening to, if just because of its realism. <br />As you can see, most of the songs on In Utero are good (though not spectacular). And because of that, it gets a 4/5 from me. I understand Nirvana was a very passionate band and wanted to focus more on feeling than technique. But a little technique can, in a lot of ways, add quite a bit of emotion to music. This is, ultimately, where In Utero falls flat on its face. The album hasn't aged very well (listening to it made me feel a very bad case of nostalgia), and there's very little in the way of experimentation. Once again, I understand Nirvana wanted to keep it simple, but a band with their potential could always stand to try something a little more creative once in a while. <br />Still, I recommend everybody gives In Utero a good listen. If you can look past the rough production and lack of much innovation, you'll find a very sincere, passionate, emotional record, that will definitely leave you wishing the full band was still alive and kicking.
1878424319|5.0|Lighten up your life! Many of us drag around so much mind muddle and emotional baggage. Why? Because we simply insist on it.<br />The four agreements are liberating. They teach you how to leave the heavy, unnecessary garbage(really) and move on with the most important essential of your life---you...your spirit.<br />Although this book takes the concepts of many other Life teachers and condenses wisdom into four agreements don't mistake it for a fast-food-take-out type of enlightenment. The lessons go deep, give light to your soul and take away invisible weight(enlightening), and you do have to take time to let the concepts sink in and apply to your situation.<br />The book is full of wisdom that lend you clarity and can help you find your own in-sights and who you are and not what the outside world dictates.<br />You may, as I have, get something out of the discussion on invisible agreements --- the existence of cultural and social mores that affect our lives only because we have agreed to let them rule our lives, as we didn't know any better at the time. B00006M183|5.0|The reason Pearl Jam is one of my favorite bands is also the same reason a lot of people gave up on them: their music changes and adapts. Riot Act is the next installment of Pearl Jam's journey. Their last album, Binaural, offered an experimental sound which worked for some songs, but not for others (even Brendan O'Brien was invited back to try to re-mix some songs so they would sound right). Riot Act is recorded and mixed in a more &quot;rock-traditional&quot; sound and it fits perfectly. Eddie Vedder writes beautiful lyrics relating to recent events and he even lets out a little steam on good old George W Bush. <BR>Overall, this album has more straight-forward rock. Mike McCready is allowed to let loose on a number of guitar solos throughout the album (something not seen too often in previous albums) and Matt Cameron adds an incredible Soundgarden-esque percussion which complements and enhances the Pearl Jam sound. Overall, a much more complete album than Binaural (which was still very good), with more edge and a touch of anger. But don't worry, there's still a couple of &quot;love&quot; songs. No ukeleles though.
0345446798|5.0|This wonderfully written, engrossing book explains differences in human and canine communication, without using confusing scientific jargon. Even someone who spends a considerable amount of time with dogs can gain insight from this book. Nor does it only work on puppies, like your average training book -- dogs of any age understand their own language! My 7-yr-old is responding beautifully to my attempts to communicate with her better.

B00006LLLN|3.0|I am a diehard fan of Alison Krauss and Union Station.  That said, this is a live album with all that implies.  The band's performance is of course flawless -- and I echo the &quot;What did you expect&quot; reviewer who preceded me.<br />But in my unprofessional and unsolicited opinion, the &quot;crowd noise&quot; is mixed WAY too loudly into thie album.  Usually, one hears the applause as a crowd recognizes the tune being started by the band -- and then the applause at the end, the whistles, the cheers, etc, are brought back into audibility as the song is finished.<br />Not so with this album.  I had no idea people in Kentucky had such a poor sense of rhythm.  The annoying clapping along with the music persists through some of the songs, severely detracting from the enjoyment of them. <br />This is annoying enough when one has paid to hear a performance by professional musicians and is hindered in doing so by an inconsiderate and discourteous audience.  But if you want to hear the powerful and magical performance that is &quot;Live&quot;, you have to listen to the dysrhythmic noises of the audience.  At least no loud drunk yelled &quot;Rock And Roll!&quot; or &quot;Free Bird!&quot;<br />Much as I hate to do so, I am selling this album used.  Someone with a tin ear is going to get a heck of a deal.

0671799320|5.0|&quot;The Prize&quot; is, quite simply, the best book I've ever read.  Its scope is daunting-- almost 800 pages-- and it took me months to get enough time to complete it. But every time I had to put it down, I couldn't wait to get back to it.  Yergin's style is masterful: a complex historical epic is told as a series of succinct anecdotes, filled with colorful characters who are deftly drawn and dramatic episodes that are vivid and alive. Along the way, &quot;The Prize&quot; provides an amazing education on the development of modern industry, the creation of the global economy, and just about every important historical event of the past 150 years. This is a compelling book: read it and you will have a far greater understanding of world events, both past and present.
B00005OMTT|4.0|When Enigma started to sound in Spain I must say I didn't like at all. I hated Sadeness. Now is one of my favourite songs in the history of music. I started apreciating 1 or 2 years later listening to my dad's CD. I rate 4 out from 5 cos there are some changes I would do in the best songs album. As I've read from you, jerry, the 2 songs you like are instrumental and more or less soft, relaxing. 1st cd, MCMXCa.c. has 2 \\"strong\\" songs (Principles of lust, which contains Sadeness and Find love, and Mea culpa), 1 intro as every Enigma cd, 3 more relaxing (Callas went away, Knockin on forbidden doors and Rivers of belief) and the other one is like an intro (The voice and the snake). <BR>2nd one, Cross of changes is, perhaps, stronger (Return to innocence, I love you...I'll kill you-which I love-, Silent warrior, Age of loneliness and Out of the deep). There is one long instrumental (Eyes of truth) and 2 short \\"melodics\\" (Dream of the dolphin and the cd closing Cross of changes).<BR>3rd, Le roi et mort, vive le roi (King is dead, Life for the King in french). More calm songs (Morphin thru time, Shadows in silence, Almost full moon and Odyssey of the mind), and 3 stronger (Why, TNT for the brain and Roundabout). The other 3 are relaxin I think (the single Beyond the invisible, Child in us and Prism of life).<BR>Finally, The screen behind the mirror: 5 strongs (Push the limits, Gravity of love, Modern crusaders, Camera obscura and Silence must be heard). 5 relaxin (Traces, Screen behind the mirror, Endless quest, Between heart and mind and my favourite Smell of desire).<BR>I think four of them are very similar in that way, maybe second is the strongest and could be worse for you. Try with 1st or 3rd, but if you have the oportunity make yourself a mix with the calmest songs I recomend you: Callas went away, Knockin on forbidden doors, Rivers of belief, Beyond the invisible, Shadows in silence, Almost full moon, Traces, Between mind and heart and Smell of desire. Take into account that there are not breaks between songs in the cd's if you want to mix them. It seems me a bit unfair not to include my 2 favourite songs: Principles of lust (12 minutes) and I love you...I'll kill you (9 minutes). They mix strong and calm passages.<BR>ciao
0440180295|5.0|On February 13-14, in the year of 1945, 65,000 incendiary explosives were dropped upon the peaceful and beautiful German city of Dresden by British and American forces, burning 135,000 men, women, and children to death (15,000 more than the nuclear bombing of Hiroshima).  So it goes.<BR>The author of Slaughterhouse-Five, Kurt Vonnegut, was one of the 100 people to survive the bombing, and then only because he was deep under the ground in a slaughterhouse being held as a prisoner of war.  For the main character of the story, Kurt Vonnegut invented Billy Pilgrim, the imaginary protagonist of Slaughterhouse-Five, to also witness the somewhat unknown firebombing of Dresden.  The damage that the event inflicted upon Billy's mind becomes apparent throughout the course of the book, beginning with the fact that he experiences time by jumping from event to event in his life, similar to a severely shell-shocked individual.               <BR>The story is presented in a calm and informative manner, with absurd, disturbing, and often unexpected events mixed with the often mundane and uneventful story of Billy's life.  It is through these bizarre events that many of the book's main points are presented; for instance, aliens known as the Tralfamadorians (who view the universe through the fourth-dimension) kidnapped Billy Pilgrim in his warped mind and showed him that the true way to view the universe was to see it all at once, as a huge picture, and then to focus only on the times that were pleasant.   <BR>In my opinion, Slaughterhouse-Five is a book that should be read by every human being on the planet.  Who knows, maybe people might realize that destroying people's lives and minds over issues they don't have anything to do with won't make the world a better place.

B000002UJQ|5.0|To hell with catchy poppy tunes like Radiohead's ticket song, Creep. Radiohead treks on into a new stage on OK Computer. The clang and clatter of OK Computer just sounds like pots and pans at first but once you get it into your head there's no getting rid of it. On Ok Computer the Oxford quintet create their best album ever. with melodical hooks, tantilizing guitar riffs, stirring drum beats and haunting lyrics they make one of the best records of the nineties. From beginning to end the album is infectious and intriguing. It starts with the cello-like guitar driven Airbag that dazzles and soars. It ends with the calm and relaxing The Tourist that keeps you humming. But the album shines like no album ever shines about two and a half minutes into the epic Paranoid Android. When singer Thom Yorke sings \\"You Don't Remember!\\" and the guitar punches in, it's the most surprising and memerable moment in most any song. The entire 6 and a half minutes of Paranoid Android is gripping. but the highlight of the album is the hair raising Exit Music (For A Film). it starts with just a whisper, then a soothing echo of melody that bursts into a pounding chorus that slurs back into a waning whisper. The whole album is essentially about chaos. Subterranian Homesick Alien addresses the idea of alien's being disgusted with humanity if they ever laid eyes on it. Karma Police expresses Radiohead's view of the hypocrites that consume the radio (\\"He buzzes like a fride. He's like a detuned radio.\\") All in all OK Computer is one of the best records of the 90s and won't let you down. 10/10 Highlights: \\"Exit Music (For A Film)\\" \\"Paranoid Android\\" \\"Lucky\\" \\"Karma Police\\" \\"Airbag\\"
B00006LIRI|3.0|If you were expecting the qualitative equivalanet to U2's first compilation of singles, 'Best of 1980-1990', you will find this one a bit of a disappointment, even if you liked the music of U2 from 1990 to 2000.  Here's a song-by-song review:<br />1. \\"Even Better Than the Real Thing\\".  As the fourth single from their most successful record of the decade, 'Achtung Baby' (1991), this pop dity, appropriately the opening track, has excellent guitar work and a lyrical irony that would characterize the \\"reinvention\\" of U2 in its second decade.<br />2. \\"Mysterious Ways\\".  As one of their most popular singles and live songs from 'Achtung Baby', the underwater guitar sound, the funky bass-line, and a distinct lyrical shift into the secular (or is it?) would yield success of U2's debut as a pop band.  (NOTE: For U2 fans, a line is changed from the original at 1:43.)<br />3. \\"Beautiful Day\\".  If you don't know this one, a dose of optimism and heavy guitars hearlding the first single from the \\"return-to-their-roots\\" record, 'All That You Can't Leave Behind' (2000), you have probably been living under a rock.<br />4. \\"Electric Storm\\" [William Orbit Mix].  As the first of two new songs on this release, it is curious that the band included a remix on the original compilation.  While the first 50 seconds are appropriate for the accompanying lyrics, this remix lacks the venom of the original version of the song (included only on the Limited Edition bonus disc), the quality of which lies somewhere between just-good and classic.<br />5. \\"One\\".  If any song of U2 in the 1990s will be remembered, it is \\"One\\", a bittersweet ballad with multiple interpretations, which has been covered by a number of artists (e.g., Johnny Cash, R.E.M.) and would have been just as big of a hit as the other contender for U2's best ballad (\\"With or Without You\\") if it had a catchier chorus.<br />6. \\"Miss Sarajevo\\".  This sleepy tune is the one single and sole entry included from the U2/Brian Eno collaboration, 'Passengers: Original Soundtracks' (1995).  Unfortunately, because of the deletion more than one minute, what was a stunning guest performance by Pavorati on the original version seems awkward immediately following Bono's subdued verse on the edited version here.<br />7. \\"Stay (Faraway, So Close!)\\".  This relatively traditional and mellow single from U2's exploration into art rock, 'Zooropa' (1993), moves along nicely, with its value as a U2 classic derived from the lyrical imagry and fine vocal performance by Bono.<br />8. \\"Stuck in a Moment You Can't Get Out Of\\".  Although the lyrics are a bit hokey for Bono, this single was originally an ode to the deceased INXS singer who killed himself in 1997 that took on new meaning in the nationwide grief post-9/11.  Nonetheless, it seems a bit out of place among the tracks from the 1990s.  (NOTE:  This single was not actaully released until 2001, which is when the Grammy-winning \\"Walk On\\" and Elevation\\" were also released, leading me to wonder why these stronger tracks were not also included.)<br />9. \\"Gone\\" [New Mix].  As one of the three tracks from the much-maligned 'Pop' (1997) record, this one was not a single, but it is hard to argue against its inclusion on this compilation, as this plodding rocker is a lyrical highpoint of the U2 canon and has remained a live staple.  On this \\"new mix\\", certain vocals and guitar parts have been re-recorded and the middle section has been re-arranged to mirror the live version - unfortunately, the result is flat and uninspiring when compared to the original.<br />10. \\"Until the End of the World\\".  This is another strong non-single rocker, this time from 'Achtung Baby', which lyrically a conversation between Jesus and Judas.  It has rightfully remained within the U2 live set for a decade.<br />11. \\"The Hands That Built America\\".  This is the other new song on this compilation and the theme to the upcoming film 'Gangs of New York'.  Initially, it comes across as a over-orchestrated and uninteresting ballad; when Bono's filtered, operatic vocal break shows up in the middle, you may find yourself cringing; and with the thrown-in lyrical reference to 9/11 at the end (without any real contextual connection to the rest of the song), one has to wonder what were they thinking?!  <br />12. \\"Discotheque\\" [New Mix].  As one of the most controversial singles and introduction to the poorly-received 'Pop' record, this version is the most different from the remixes here.  Unfortunately, where the original version was pumped up with many sonic colors and heavy beats, wonderfully closing the seemingly wide gap between club music and metal, this version is, quite simply, unfulfilling by comparison.<br />13. \\"Hold Me, Thrill Me, Kiss Me, Kill Me\\".  The non-LP single from the 'Batman Forever' (1995) soundtrack is a welcome inclusion here, an autobiographical rocker which characterizes U2-in-the-1990s - \\"You don't know what you're doin' - babe, it must be art\\".<br />14. \\"Staring at the Sun\\" [New Mix].  As the second and perhaps most well-received single from the 'Pop' record, members of the band have often stated that they could never get the tempo right on this one (as an ill-fated attempt at the song in the opening night of the PopMart tour would prove).  However, the added drum tracks in this remix here only adds a sense of disjointedness as compared to the original.<br />15. \\"Numb\\" [New Mix].  In the attempts to rewrite parts of U2's second decade by including several remixes, this is the one that was tampere with the least, and as such, may actually be better than the original, which was easily their most experimental and controversial \\"single\\" ever.  In this version, the vocals have been moved up in the mix (so you can actually here what the Edge is chanting . . . well, kind of), the Bono's falsetto of the chorus (\\"I feel numb\\") in the original has been replaced by the deadpan voice of an unnamed singer who actually sounds numb (drummer, Larry Mullen, I presume),  and some guitar has been added to make the sound a bit more anthemic.<br />16. \\"The First Time\\".  This is the third non-single track included on the compilation, and while lyrically strong, the minimalist musical elements are far to similar to a previous U2 hit (\\"All I Want Is You\\") to warrant inclusion here.  On this note, one has to wonder, where are the more experimental singles that defined the decade (such as \\"The Fly\\" and \\"Lemon\\") or even the stronger more traditional-U2 releases (such as \\"Please\\" or the single semi-acoustic version of \\"Wild Horses\\")?  Whatever the answer, this compilation could have been bettter constructed and pales by comparison to its 1980s counterpart, even if you liked U2 in the 1990s.
B000002TYK|3.0|When Dave Grohl sings \\"I'll stick around\\" he ain't wrong. The ex-Nirvana drummer is sticking around. His band has gripped the ears of rock lovers everywhere. With his breakthrough record Grohl shows the world he's not just the drummer of the most successful rock band of the '90s. B00006M183|4.0|And here it is, PJ's latest offering. Admittedly I felt disappointed on first listen. Why? No tunes besides the 1st single grabbed me. But then again, listening to it as background music with your kids screaming & carrying on in the same room doesn't help. Now, after a few thorough listens via headphones & without interruptions, I've fallen in love with the record, as with all past PJ releases(except maybe for No Code).<BR>We are still left with an album with no real potential commercially appealing singles. I Am Mine is a good example. As great as that song is, it is not what the mass market are after any more. The kids these days are not interested in hearing what any band has to say after their 2nd album. Why? Simple; someone else has come along & replaced them. Replaced that void.<BR>That is what's happened to Pearl Jam. BUT not for the fans, & those who can be objective enough & dedicate the time to have a good listen. This album ROCKS! It is a continuation of Binaural, which continued on from Yield(to a lesser extent).<BR>What is surprising here is that the drummer Matt Cameron has contributed so much to the writing(both music & lyrics). Below's a quick rating(from 10) for each song. Without a doubt this could change after many more listens...<BR>1. Can't Keep - great lyrics. Interesting melody line. Good arrangement. (8)<BR>2. Save You - Straight fwd rock song. Hints of old PJ. (7)<BR>3. Love Boat Captain - more of that experimental stuff. They pull it off here. Brilliant lyrics! Only drawback is the sudden change in melody at around 1:30 into it. Great bridge. (9)<BR>4. Cropduster - interesting 7/8 timing in verses. Otherwise nothing really new here. (7)<BR>5. Ghost - another straight fwd rock tune. (7)<BR>6. I Am Mine - excellent! (10)<BR>7. Thumbing My Way - brilliant change of pace. Good placement on album too. WOuld love to see Bruce Springsteen do a version, or at least get up on stage & sing with Eddie. (10)<BR>8. You Are - love the distortion here! Must be Matt's idea for the song. Would like to hear them do more of this stuff. Can be a surprisingly successful single. (10)<BR>9. Get Right - another Cameron contribution. Great guitar sound here. Verse structure has hints of early Midnight Oil. (9)<BR>10. Green Disease - great song, although sounds like parts were borrowed from a few places. The ending on verses sounds not unlike XTC's Senses Working Overtime. (8)<BR>11. Help Help - see 10. Great build-up going on throughout this one. (9)<BR>12. Bushleaguer - one of the best tracks! Great choice as B-side to I Am Mine.(10)<BR>13. Half Full - Rhythm too similar to Rival from Binaural. (7)<BR>14. Arc - PJ always throw one of these obscure tracks on. I like it. Very Middle-Eastern sounding. Choice or coincidence? (9)<BR>15. All Or None - would be interesting to see the other tracks PJ contemplated putting on as a closer. This slow number is nothing special. (7)<br />Overall, a great CD. One gets the feeling that Eddie is trying to say too much in some songs. Like the older classic tunes they wrote, he needs to remind himself that often less-IS-more! I think it's only a matter of time 'till Eddie releases a solo effort. Some tunes here would sit well on that, such as Thumbing & All Or None. <BR>If u're a devoted PJ fan, u will NOT be disappointed. If u are new to them, start with something else, like VS or Vitalogy(Ten was different to anything they did after). In fact, those two are probably their most underated efforts. Underated u ask? Yes, because they should be regarded as rock masterpieces, of any era since Rock was born almost 50 years ago! <br />Pearl Jam & Eddie Rock!!!

Anticipating a hefty bonus from his employer, he places an order for a swimming pool, invites his parents and in-laws to his home, and eagerly looks forward to enjoying an old-fashioned \\"family Christmas.\\"<br />Of course, everything goes horribly wrong--the tree, the lights, family squabbles, snooty neighbors, a coldhearted boss and an unexpected visit from Cousin Eddie (Randy Quaid is priceless). All of the mayhem wears on poor Clark until he finally snaps...the result of his \\"breakdown\\" is complete comic bliss.<br />This Griswold saga is second only to the original \\"Vacation\\" as the funniest movie in this series. B000002GJH|5.0|Before Pearl Jam came out with their first album and soundgarden really established themselves, they recorded this excellent tribute album to the recently deceased Andrew Wood of Mother Love Bone.<BR>With all the emotion involved, the members of Pearl Jam and Soundgarden united to create a truly amazing rock/grunge album.  <BR>The first track \\"Say Hello 2 Heaven\\" is a brilliant song with Cornell adding just the right amount of soul and tilt to the vocals.  Excellent lyrics such as \\"words never listen and teachers never learn.\\"  Bolstered by a killer Mike McCready guiatr solo this is one of the best songs on the album.<BR>Next comes the monster \\"Reach Down\\" with 11 minutes of guitar pyrotechniques by Stone Gossard and McCready.  Cornell absolutely WAILS on this song with his unbelievable vocal range.  If you dig long and loud guitar solos this is a great song, if you enjoy more punchier and concise solos this is most likely boring and you'll like the next song much better.<br />\\"Hunger Strike\\" follows next with the excellent interplay between Eddie Vedder and Chris Cornell.  This is the one song most people remember from this album mainly because it's played on the radio.  It is a great song but a bit overrated.<BR>Temple continues on with the rock atmosphere with \\"Pushin' Forward Back.\\"  This sounds like a demo from Pearl Jam's \\"Ten\\" with the soaring guitars and driving drums.  The fake ending is a nice suprise too.<BR>\\"Call Me a Dog\\" is a decent power ballad.  Mike's solo is the high point and the song really builds to greatness at the end.<BR>\\"Times of Trouble\\" is a blatant reference to Andrew Wood's drug problems which eventually killed him.  This is one of the high points of the album especially with Cornell ripping it up on the Harmonica.  Pearl Jam's song \\"Footsteps\\" has the same melody but with  different lyrics and can be found on the \\"Jeremy\\" single.<BR>Next comes \\"Wooden Jesus\\" and \\"Your Savior.\\"  In my opinion these are the low points of the album.  Thereisn't a lot of musical development going on.  Decent at best.<BR>\\"Four Walled World\\" follows being one of if not THE best song on the album.  Seven miuntes of pure grunge.  All members contribute emensely to this track.  Drummer Matt Cameron is pounding on the drums like his life depended on it, Stone provides a killer riff, Jeff's Bass is nicely present with some cool runs, Cornell is wailing his best and mike is spectaular on the end solo.  All this leads up to a great ending with cornell crooning \\"oh yeah!!<BR>\\"All Night Thing\\" is a nice breath of fresh air after the firestorm of \\"four walled world.\\"  <BR>The is a fabulous album with so much emotion and great performances all around.  If you're tired with all the radio friendly wanna be grunge bands (Creed, Nickelback, Puddle of Mudd, Staind, Bush, Default.  None of them from Seattle I might add) this album is great.  If you like guitar solos, superb drumming, soundgarden, pearl jam, grunge, rock and roll, excellent vocals, genuine emotion and just plain great music pick this up.  As great as this album is, it gets better with each listen.

B00005OAIE|4.0|I bought the John Mayer CD the other day just to see if he truly was a DMB wannabe or not.  (Dave Matthews happens to be my favorite band by the way.)  I put the CD in my car stereo and took off driving.  At first I was a bit confused and thought I had accidently bought a new DMB album that I didnt even know existed. (He even had a song on his album named '83')  Then as I listened I noticed that Mayer actually has a sound of his own.  Even though his singing is remarkably close to that of Dave's, his guitar riffs are more upbeat and have more variation with less strumming and more picking.  I thought to myself he is just living a little kid's dream (atleast I always dreamed of being Dave Matthews) and since his music isnt quite as catchy as Dave's he would die out as quickly as he came in.  But even if he does it is still fun to listen to a new song once in awhile in between my looping tracks of Dave Matthews Band that I listen to all day long. Especially the song Your Body is a Wonderland. (This song sounds like it would fit in nicely with Dave's older stuff he used to write.) I would recommend this to anyone who likes Dave Matthews, but dont throw out the old Crash CD to make room for this one, because you will soon find yourself coming back to it.

B00006M183|5.0|Pearl Jam has long been undergoing an evolution, from the experimentation of No Code, the emotive calm of Yield, and through the slow burn of Binaural, but they definately have evolved. Riot Act serves itself as the product of those years, as a musically varied effort that, unlike Pearl Jam's last three understated works, does not need time to sink under one's skin. This album is a rocker! From the &quot;Oceans&quot;/&quot;Who You Are&quot; hybrid opener to the offspring of &quot;Indifference&quot; and &quot;All Those Yesterdays&quot; that closes the show, this album resurrects the classic rock and roll that we found in early Pearl Jam, without eshewing the progress they have made over these years. A return to form? Not quite. Frustratingly unfamiliar? Not exactly. A tremendously comfortable in between? Definately.<br />What's better is that Pearl Jam is once again ENTHUSIASTIC about promoting and declaring this album's presence to the world. Gone is the fame ducking which first irritated me in 1996. Pearl Jam loves their music again, and that makes me feel less guilty about loving it. Perhaps the reason for this newfound excitement is the decidedly Political stance which the album takes. Bashing Bush (Bushleaguer) and an uproar against the upper class (Green Disease) comes naturally. But Pearl Jam doesn't rage against the government as they did against the music industry with Vitalogy. If you disagree with Eddie and Co. this time around, you don't get a middle finger and &quot;Bugs&quot;. Instead you get a courteous agreement to disagree in &quot;I am Mine&quot;, a song which encourages everyone to form their own opinions and direct their own lives.<br />Pearl Jam's music, like the band, has become more accessible, more likable, and more intelligent.

B00006LIRI|5.0|U2&#146;s second greatest hits package stands in stark contrast to their first greatest hits album.  Listening to the two side-by-side, it almost seems as if they are two different bands.  The discrepancy in sounds shows how this band are truly gifted musicians.  The 1990&#146;s found the band sliding into the Alternative music scene with their first release of the decade, Acthung Baby.  That album is representing by the brilliant &#147;Mysterious Ways&#148;, &#147;Even Better Than The Real Thing&#148;, &#147;Until The End Of The World&#148; and the heartbreaking beautiful &#147;One&#148;.  The album and, in particular, &#147;One&#148; (which is about AIDS) showed they could adapt their music to modern styles, yet still make music with a message. Zooropa was their next and it really was an extension of Acthung Baby, but it moved them even more away from their main sounds.  Pop was a complete move into electronica and really sounds nothing like a U2 record.  Long time fans were displeased with the album and the press jumped all over the band.  While it is clearly the weakest album the band has made, they should be applauded for not standing still and have a willingness to experiment with new sounds.  They also did some movie soundtrack work in the 1990&#146;s with songs like &#147;Miss Sarajevo&#148; and the overlooked &#147;Hold Me, Thrill Me, Kiss Me, Kill Me&#148; from Batman Forever which is one of their best singles as well as contributing album tracks &#147;Stay (Faraway, So Close!)&#148; and &#147;Until The End Of The World&#148; to soundtracks (One of the two new tracks &#147;The Hands That Built America&#148; is also from a movie, Martin Scorcese&#146;s Gangs Of New York).  In 2000, the band returned to a more traditional U2 sound with All That You Can&#146;t Leave Behind.  The album was universally hailed and produced the glorious &#147;Beautiful Day&#148; that won a slew of Grammys.  The album contains two new songs, but it also has new mixes of songs like &#147;Discotheque&#148;, &#147;Numb&#148; and others.  U2 is one of the biggest rock groups in the world, but they are constantly evolving their sound and refuse to rest on their laurels.  Not all of the sound changes they have attempted have worked, but they are constantly challenging their fans and keeping them entertained in the process.&#147;Discotheque&#148;, &#147;Numb&#148; and others. Not all of the sound changes they have attempted have worked, but they are constantly challenging their fans and keeping them entertained in the process.
