B00005JKCH|3.0|SPIDER-MAN raked in another ... million in just the first three days of it's home video release.  That brings the world-wide gross to about a billion bucks.  An off the chart figure.  So what is it about this story that connected with a global audience on such a stratospheric level?  Was it the marketing, the name recognition from the seemingly endless series of comic book incarnations or something else?<br /><br />If the film does not hold up as well as one might guess on repeated viewings, the metaphors for the frustrations and fantasies of male puberty come though even clearer.  Perhaps more than anything, this film is a romantic rite of passage; almost tribal in its subtext (the ritual spider bite and the shamanistic hallucinations of flying and fighting demons) but in a post-modern garb.<br /><br />But does it all add up to anything?  Not really.  Perfectly directed by super-visualist Sam Raimi (a master of the floating camera), and with nice, understated, naturalistic performances by Tobey Maguire and Kirsten Dunst.  These two actors exude a rare and apparently authentic chemistry in their scenes together.  Inexplicably, Maguire is missing on the entertaining audio commentary with Raimi and Dunst. Interesting but rather ordinary making-of and behind-the-scenes extras on the second disc.

0553801481|5.0|I've just finished this book, the seventh in Hobb's magic world of intrigue, romance and balls-to-the-walls action.  They've all been well written, well plotted and imaginative, with this Fool's Errand as good as the original Assassin's Apprentice.  Read them in order, though -- they're all worth it.<br />Hobb's style is a kind of cross between Ursula K. Le Guin's Earthsea trilogy and Robert Jordan's massive Wheel of Time.  She has Ms. Le Guin's heart wrenching purity and characterization, and she has Mr. Jordan's fine story telling and action sequences.  Painfully, she also has George R. R. Martin's exquisite sense of tragedy, crashing the reader into despair on a regular basis, then lifting them back to a peak of relieved joy.<br />I realize I've just compared Ms. Hobb to three of my favorite modern fantasy writers.  She may be the best of the lot.  Read these books.

0385470819|5.0|Near the rural town of Clanton, Mississippi, little Tonya Hailey is brutally raped, beaten, and left for dead by two drunken and remorseless men. The rapists are almost immediately caught in a roadside bar, where they have been bragging of their exploits. When the men appear in court days later, Tonya's father Carl bursts out of the courthouse basement, and executes them with an assault rifle. Murder or execution? Justice or revenge? Carl trusts his life to only one man in town - local criminal lawyer Jake Brigance, who dreams of famous cases, headlines, and the big time. Jake is about to face the fight of his life, and he knows it. Not only is he up against Rufus Buckley - a tough, ambitious district attorney who realizes that a murder conviction could help him gain higher office - but he has a much bigger problem: the rapists are white, the judge is white, the jury is white - and Carl is black. This is a trial sure to change forever the lives of everyone involved.<br /> A Time To Kill is a riveting novel that challenges everything we think we know about justice and equality.
B0000026CM|5.0|Every ten years or so an album comes along that reminds me of all things good in music.  I bought this album in 1988.  Only recently while going back through my CDs did I come across it again.  In the 14 or so years that have past since this album hit the streets, many many bands have come and gone and tens of thousands of songs, good and bad, have been played but few albums that I have listened to over the years still give me goosebumps like The Seventh One still does.  I'm not sure if it is hearing the brilliance of Jeff Porcaro on Mushanga or the impecable drive of Steve Lukather but what ever it is everyone needs to hear it. <br />If you can only buy one album this year, buy this one.  If you have it already and haven't listened to it in a long time like me, pull it out and pop it in.  Let the music take you back.  You will be glad that you did.

B000065VB9|5.0|For a long time I didn't know how to stop listening to this album. Up until SO this is probably his most accessible record, but it's a very weird one as well. It starts off with \\"Intruder,\\" with a hypnotic drum into and suspenseful chords telling the story of a man who knows \\"how to creep across creaky wooden floors.\\" The album starts off unsettling, and then we go into \\"No Self Control,\\" a man who has OCD, with one of the most thrilling choruses I've ever heard. \\"Start\\" is a synth intro to \\"I Don't Remember\\" and it's a plot-setter type of track like those instrumentals in The Lamb lies Down On Broadway, Gabriel's stellar finale with Genesis. Then after 1:20, we go into one of the most disturbing cuts on the album, with Peter's manic howl letting the guitars in. <BR><BR>\\"Family Snapshot\\" is an emotional view of an assassin who shoots a politician before flashing back to a lonely childhood with a souring relationship between his parents, with some very emotional vocals by Gabriel (his specialty). \\"And Through The Wire\\" and \\"Games Without Frontiers\\" are probably the two 'pop' songs on the album, with catchy hooks. \\"Not One Of Us,\\" is a song dealing with conformity containing the quote \\"It's only water in a stranger's tear.\\" Then there's the mostly instrumental \\"Lead A Normal Life,\\" before the finale and ultimately the focal point on the album, \\"Biko\\" a tribute to the South African anti-apartheid icon Stephen Biko who was murdered in prison in 1977. With emotional lyrics and vocals by Gabriel, it's easily the best protest song of the 1980s, and one of the best songs ever.

0783231032|5.0|OK, OK, I admit this movie is a bit sophmoric, but if that worked in 'Animal House', why can't it work here?  I loved this movie, and those who are overly critical of it need to realize that simple humor does work.  Notice I said 'simple' and not 'stupid', which in light of recent box office releases such as 'Jackass' seem to be somewhat popular.<br />What makes this movie more poignant is September 11th.  Now, I know it isn't good form to make fun of the recent terrorist attacks, but the reaction by the US mirrors the events following the attack on Pearl Harbor, which this film makes fun of.  Trust me, I am in the US military, and people we racking their brains in trying to guess what, where and how the next attack would occur.  I read reports of people in small towns in west central Texas thinking they would be the next target.  It was the same paranoia that occurred after December 7th.<br />I don't advocate taking terrorism any less serious, nor do I want to downplay the heroic actions of those in NYC, the Pentagon, or on the plane that crashed in Pennsylvania; but we spun ourselves through the roof (and still do) with a \\"ready, fire, aim\\" mentality.  Panic does not help, and the best thing to do is cool down and think clearly.  I think this films shows us how ridiculous \\"war nerves\\" can make us all!  Well worth the money!

0812550706|5.0|*** Contains Spoilers ***  Ender's Game deserves more than to be one of the best Sci-Fi books of all time.  It has all the elements: space, galactic war, imperial powers beyond individual control. In the end, though, Ender's Game is one of the great coming-of-age novels ever written, write up there with &#34;Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man&#34; and &#34;Catcher in the Rye.&#34;  The story follows a young man through trials that force him into adulthood.  Ender is the perfect young man:  intelligent, angry at his powerlessness, his views fixed by his parents and society as an outcast. Through the story we see him grow, but not through contrived dialogue and classic &#34;firsts.&#34;  There is no loss of virginity, or facial hair, or &#34;chats&#34; with pop.  Ender learns to win through competition; he learns of the power of force through beatings.  He learns of oppression through futile dealings with magistrates.  He also learns of camaraderie from friends, and of himself through isolation. The two greatest lessons he learns, however, are the tragedy of the story.  He learns objectivity only too late, despite a video game that begs his attention to it repeatedly; when he exterminates a race of beings with whom he feels an unknown connection.  And he learns responsibility when he devotes his life to preserving their memory. I would recommend this book to anyone and everyone.  It is the story of the future, but don't relegate it to the sci-fi shelves.  For it is also a story of struggle, pain, of mistakes, and of learning.  It deserves to be right up there on the classics rack.

B00003CXMG|4.0|This movie is one about coming of age through change.  It follows three main characters:  a young writer for Rolling Stone, the leader of a Led Zeppelin-like band in the 70's, and a beautiful groupie.<br />Each person is faced with intense highs and terrible tragedies at the hands of the others throughout the story.  The strength of the movie is that, instead of shoehorning the characters into roles and making them tragic heroes, it instead makes the events change them.  By the end, it's the Rock hero that looks up to the writer, the suicidal groupie that mothers the other two into an understanding, and the aspiring writer who fails at writing but still finds his dream.<br />A huge part of the movie is probably the soundtrack, a collection of original works and the best soaring rock of the 1970's.<br />Excellent movie.  Even when it falls into the trap of being saccharine, it at least avoids seeming contrived.  I would recommend it to any nostalgic baby boomer, confused teenager, or wild gen-Xer.

The live &quot;I Can't Quit You&quot; from a Royal Albert Hall rehearsal sounds so vivid that one hopes they will release the whole show in its entirety some day.<BR> <BR>Years later, with the release of the BBC sessions and their remasters, Led Zep did their musical legacy proud, and fans interested in exploring more should get either the Box Sets or the aforementioned BBC CD instead.<br />Avoid Coda if you can - it doesn't really do much to enhance the experience of listening to a great band like Zep.

0385495323|5.0|It's said that a good writer can make any subject interesting. In \\"The Code Book\\", Simon Singh takes an interesting subject and makes it not only fascinating - but understandable. <br />Singh has a PhD in physics as well as a talent for incorporating lucid explanations into a well-told story. His book offers a historical survey of the ongoing struggle between those who create encrypted (disguised) messages and the enemies who would decode those messages. The book is a only a survey, not an authoritative history, but it gives a tremendous feel for the subject. It ranges from ancient times to present-day efforts in the mysterious world of quantum cryptography. Throughout, Singh's thorough and illuminating analogies and explanations make the encryption and decryption techniques themselves accessible to the intellectually curious layperson.<br />\\"The Code Book\\" was published before 9/11/01, but after reading it, you'll wonder if the US National Security Agency (NSA) is focused right now on building a quantum computer that can crack encrypted terrorist messages. I'm guessing they are, with as much urgency as Alan Turing and his colleageus in England worked to crack Germany's \\"Enigma\\" machine in World War II (read all about that in Singh's book). And if they succeed, it will have enormous implications for online privacy and security. Which, incidentally, is a subject that Singh also covers in an effective, objective manner when he recounts the development of \\"Pretty Good Privacy\\" in the 1990's.<br />\\"The Code Book\\" should appeal broadly to anyone who is the slightest bit curious about this fascinating subject. Encryption isn't just the stuff of spies and nerdy mathematicians, it is (and has been) of vital importance throughout history. Side note: Technology managers who want to gain a fuller appreciation for the methods and circumstances of modern-day, computer-enabled encryption should read this book.
B00006JSS8|5.0|this man is a legend! i just called to say i love you, and isn't she lovely, are two of the best songs ever! go stevie, u rule!x
0195145925|4.0|Julian Barbour has presented some fantastic ideas that I really like.  In a nutshell, he claims that our current framework for physics [absolute space and time] is a problem and he instead suggests what he calls &quot;Platonia&quot; as the framework.  In Platonia, time does not exist, nor absolute space.  The important thing is where the matter in the universe is relative to all the other matter in the universe [relative configuration].  <BR>  When a scientific theory breaks down, the first thing to do is check the assumptions that are built into the theory.  Given the failure of even finding a Unified Theory [or Theory of Everything], particularly with the definition of time, it is about &quot;time&quot; that physicists started examining their assumptions.  The assumptions that are under suspicion are the very existence of absolute time and space.  [Does space exist as the box that we put matter into, or is it the matter that exists and we draw the box around it in order to describe it?]<BR>  Hooray for Dr. Barbour for having the courage to challenge our most sacred cows!  I hope others will take up the challenge as it appears there is much to be done.<BR>  The reading is a bit dense at times and some of the analogies he uses were better left out [they are more confusing than illuminating].  I would have appreciated some mathematical examples.  I worry that he may have missed the mark in going into too much detail for the non-physicist and not enough detail for the physicist.

B00005MP58|5.0|Since it became fashionable in recent times to adapt Jane Austin novels to film, this jewel of a masterpiece from A&amp;E/BBC(respectively) has the most interesting performances from a brilliant cast; a great script to reel you in and keep you there; elegant and meticulous art direction you'd expect from a British production; and marvelous direction which altogether affords the viewer the chance to really get attached to these beloved characters. B00006JIAF|5.0|I've had a year to digest the music of the three &quot;It&quot; band sweepstakes: White Stripes, the Hives and the Strokes. Don't get me wrong; I dearly love the two former mentioned bands, but the Strokes are hands down winners. White Stripe's Jack White is the most compelling front man of the lot, with his nose-thumbing anger at the musical establishment and the papparazzi. White Stripes are an off kilter delight that blaze away with the same kinetic energy of the legendary Boston band, the Pixies. The Hives are closest to the spirit of '76 with their inspired anarchy and anti-establishment anger. You will never hear an American band as overtly leftist as the Hives. I still don't get the dopey British Invasion suits and ties, but it is a ironic contrast to assembly line hipness of other so called &quot;alternative&quot; bands. The Strokes are the quintessential New York rock band. I think comparisions to the Velvets are fair to that extent, but Julian Casablancas' voice is capable of more range and expression than most New York singers, who have a tradition of dark, atonal, sing-song intonations. The twin guitar attack of Albert Hammond and Nick Valensi are in the tradition of the clean and powerful exchanges between Television's Tom Verlaine and Richard Lloyd. The glue that holds together the Strokes, however, is the cascading bass lines of Nikolai Fraiture and the solid one drop drumming of Fab Moretti. This is a band with a lot of great ideas and they have carved out enough musical space to be around for years.

B000002LMM|5.0|&quot;My (musical) world is a little bit dark. . . a little bit off-center. I think of it as tragically beautiful. Even when David Lynch writes some lyrics for Julee Cruise to sing, the mood produced by the music never changed.  It is amazing to me how you could always be aware of what Badalamenti was doing while watching &quot;Twin Peaks,&quot; yet the music never becomes intrusive or overwhelming.  Instead it is a perfect compliment to the story and pictures.  And remember:<br />That gum you like, it's coming back in style...e...

0553274503|5.0|Charlie Gordon is a retard, but an operation boosts his intelligence so that he becomes a genius. However, it becomes clear that the operation might start regressing and he may end up as retarded as when he started. The story is skilfully told in diary form, with the writing accurately reflecting the mental ability of Gordon. We watch through Gordon's eyes his mental ascent to unassailable heights; fumbling with his emotional development as it lags behind his intellect; coming to terms with his past....and brooding upon his eventual future. Although the story is sad on so many levels, the book is never depressing and always compelling. This is because Keyes is a writer of skill and subtlety, and deserves to be known to a wider audience than his narrow science fiction base. A minor 20th Century classic.

1563898586|5.0|The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen is perhaps the best comic of the 21st century. Its premise is totally original: gather already established literary characters past their primes and have them go on a mission. Moore sets himself up well, since he has unlimited characters. B000002UA9|4.0|In order to truly appreciate the Beatle's debut, &quot;Please Please Me&quot; one has to understand that recording techniques were more primitive than 2002, using mono and 4-8 tracks.  They also did this album in about two days.  It helped that they had been playing most of these songs in their live set for some time.  All the pieces are here for what's to come from the John, Paul, Ringo and George:  nice vocal harmonies, chiming guitars and a taste of R&amp;B pop.  True, the tracks are raw, but that makes the energy all the better and more exuberant.<br />Who cares if the majority of the songs are covers, again, that was the norm of the day.  John and Paul were still budding songwriters.  Besides, all for Beatles get a lead vocal feature, which very few bands today can do.<br />&quot;I Saw Her Standing There&quot; is one of the great rockers of all time.  Great vocals by Paul, cool bassline, twangy guitar solo by George and interesting changes.<br />&quot;Misery&quot; features some nice harmonies by John and Paul, followed by the ballad &quot;Anna&quot; and three-part harmony of John, Paul and George on &quot;Chains.&quot;<br />&quot;Boys&quot; features Ringo on lead vocals, with some nice background screaming by Paul doing his Little Richard imitation.<br />&quot;Ask me why&quot; has more nice harmonies, although the woo-woo-woo is a little dated and cheesy.  &quot;Please please me&quot; is one of the Beatles earliest singles, with some nice call/response with the &quot;come on, come on&quot; excellent harmonies and cool guitar hooks.  There's also a decent middle eight that would become a trademark for John and Paul.<br />&quot;Love Me Do&quot; is another early staple, musically simple but with more nice vocal interplay between John and Paul trading lead parts.<br />&quot;P.S. I Love You&quot; is a schmaltzy love tune, but the vocals are both earnest and naive.<br />&quot;Baby It's You&quot; is a nice cover of the David/Williams/Bacharach tune.  Check out the version on &quot;Live at the BBC.&quot;<br />&quot;Do You Want To Know a Secret&quot; is a Lennon/McCartney composition given to George.  His vocals are tentative and that Liverpool accent is pretty strong, but it's a harmless tune.<br />&quot;A Taste of Honey&quot; is well, what can I say.  Still, I like it, with the time changes and haunting melody.<br />&quot;There's a Place&quot; is probably the overlooked gem on the record, with it's urgent harmonica and super harmonies.<br />The performance of &quot;Twist and Shout&quot; is now legendary, with Lennon's raw vocals and the call/response making this version outshine the original.  How many of us have twisted with a date to this tune?ve at the BBC.&quot;<BR>&quot;Do You Want To Know a Secret&quot; is a Lennon/McCartney composition given to George.  His vocals are tentative and that Liverpool accent is pretty strong, but it's a harmless tune.<BR>&quot;A Taste of Honey&quot; is well, what can I say. How many of us have twisted with a date to this tune?

B00006M183|5.0|I have followed Pearl Jam since their debut of Ten in 1991 and they have only gotten better and better.  Their new album Riot Act tackles the big three issues : life, death and love (with a good helping of politics on the side)  They have never disguised their political activism, but this is the first album where it is impossible to ignore with songs like \\"Bushleaguer.\\"  In another song \\"Love Boat Captain\\" they address the tragedy that took place on their 2000 tour where 9 people died in Roskilde at their concert...Eddie sings \\"We lost nine friends we'll never know, two years ago today.\\"  The song concludes with a positive message, \\"all you need is love, love is all you need, love, love, love.\\"  One of the best songs on the album \\"Save You\\" is the only song on the album where Eddie screams.  It is a powerful song about the power of addiction, and the struggle to save a friend in desperate need of help.  Although this is not \\"the song\\" written for Layne Staley (that may turn up on a b-side I have heard) the message is clear, from the very first line, \\"Gonna save you f***er\\" to one of the very last \\"Please help me to help you to help yourSELLLLF!\\"  <BR>One of the greatest things about this album is the group effort behind it. There are two songs written by Jeff Ament (music and words) that are absolutely amazing and like nothing you have ever heard before from this band.  Matt Cameron (former Soundgarden drummer) adds two songs to the album, one of which (\\"You Are\\") has a Nine-Inch-Nails-esque quality to it.  It is a very sexy song and like nothing you have ever heard Pearl Jam play before.  Eddie plays a solo on here with \\"Thumbing My Way\\" where he sounds very Bruce Springsteen.  There is also a 1-minute track towards the end of the album called \\"Arc\\" and any fan of Nusrat Fateh Ali Kahn will smile when they hear it.  (It is clearly a tribute) Eddie experiments with his voice on this track in a way that he has never before on any album.  <BR>Another key to what makesthis album so stunning and fresh is the fact that they have, after all these years, finally added a keyboardist!  \\"Boom\\" a friend of Eddie's from Hawaii has lent his help to the album and really transformed their sound.  He will also be playing on the tour with them this upcoming year and re-working older songs like \\"Black\\" and \\"Betterman\\" giving them a fresh new taste with the keyboard.  <BR>If you love Pearl Jam this album is a MUST HAVE.  If you gave up on Pearl Jam after their second or third album, this is the one where you owe it to yourself to pick this album up and give it a listen.  YOU WILL BE AMAZED!

B0000714B5|5.0|1. The plot.  The Nobel prize winner, Hermann Hesse, wrote Siddhartha in 1922. It is a novel about Eastern spirituality (many Indian scholars consider it as one of the few succesful examples of Indian philosophy presented by a Western author). Siddhartha is one of the names given to the Buddha himself.  The novel narrates the pilgrimage of the son of a Brahmin, his struggle to find his own destiny; his friendship with Govinda (his \\"shadow\\"); his encounters with many different people: the Samanas (the ascetics that practice self-denial); Kamala (a courtesan who claims that she can teach and provide love as an art); Kamasawami (a rich merchant who becomes his boss); and Vasudeva... - note Vasudeva is another name given to Krishna, the teacher/driver of Arjuna in the Bhagavad-Gita).<br />2. The Movie.  In 1972, Conrad Rooks (an almost unknown movie director who made \\"Chappaqua\\" in 1966) came out with a 94-minute movie transcription of Hesse's novel.  He engaged Sven Nykvist (the famous Swedish cinematographer of Igmar Bergman) and a mainly Indian cast, including Shashi Kapoor (Siddhartha), Simi Garewal (Kamala),  Romesh Sharma (Govinda) and Zul Vellani (Vasudeva). The beautiful music was composed by Hemanta Mukherjee (I hope the soundtrack will be available soon). It will be particularly enjoyable by those who had read the book. In many of the scenes the synergism produced by the photography, the music and the acting is superb. And with few excceptions, the movie is a good transcription of the book.  The book and the movie became part of the \\"cult culture\\" of the West coast of the early seventies, but it never got the attention of the general public. With a condescending tone, Leonard Maltin refers to the movie as \\"too arty, but on-location photography ... is often dazzling\\".

From Cyberattacks to Ebola to Nuclear exchanges, it's in here.<br />I'll be honest with you as well... Unless you have a gut-of-steel, this information will make you uneasy, and will most likely frightening you. And, what makes it so scary is how it's simply based on real research and rock-solid facts. You read these scenarios, and you think, &quot;Wow... That could actually happen.&quot;<br />Otherwise, enjoy the book for what it is: Information. Because, after all, you can never have too much knowledge.

Pearl Jam reminds us of their glory days on a few of the tracks (i.e I am Mine and Love Boat Captain). The majority, however, are overly moody and pensive (even for Eddie Vedder) and seem to disolve into no particular place. The album probably should have been called \\"Side B\\" or \\"Look what I found in the bottom of this old guitar case\\". One gets the feeling that the boys got together after being hassled by their record company to fulfill their contract, and spit out whatever permeated their beer soaked brains. This is obviously not their best work, and sadly may be their worst. I certainly hope it's not their last, because there is better music that can come from these talented musicians. It will be worth the wait if they choose to make it. This, however, is not it.

B00005JKG7|4.0|Fog is an underrated and atmospheric gem. It is essential to see it in widescreen because John Carpenter keeps all sorts of good creepy things in the corners and Dean Cundy's photography is beautiful. Like \\"The BIRDS\\" the film has a nice slow build. Be patient and pay attention to all the accumilating clues of an impending supernatural event as a small town is surrounded by the spectral FOG. It has an old fashioned ghost story feel as well as shocks (most of which are supplied by truly frightening sound effects). UNFORTUNATELY the DVD is a big disappointment! GET THE SPECIAL EDITION WIDESCREEN LASERDISC on EBAY if you can. Fans of John Carpenters music should be aware the laserdisc has the music score isolated on a seperate audio track and the new DVD does NOT give us this feature. Its very important for Carpenter fans because the recently released expanded CD is really a release of the poorly done LP with new tracks made up of re-edits of the existing tracks. So much music from the film is STILL missing on the CD and the laserdisc is the only way to get it. ALSO the DVD has some outtakes as seen on the laser disc but NOT all of them. Missing on the DVD outtakes is different FX clips of the fog damaging a generator, the live FOG FX being spread thru the town, a unused moment of a rotting hand coming out of the misty water, and extra FX clips of the FOG composited on the bay. These are included on the laser though. There is an annoying visual glitch during a suspenseful moment as the FOG engulfs a house. The film freezes for a second and it really stands out like a sore thumb. This glitch is NOT on the widescreen laserdisc. While the DVD does correct a small audio glitch that the laserdisc had, they instead give us a even more noticable visual mistake. The DVD picture is slightly washed out taking the richness out of the color a bit. The FOG should have a bluish tinge to it and this transfer has it washed out to white and sometimes a very slight yellow green. Just like the DVD cover art showing the green mist which is wrong!!.

B000007O9L|4.0|If you're looking for the &quot;atmosphere&quot; of a live show, look elsewhere. Although they kick things off with the rocking &quot;Street Fighting Man&quot;, the general mood is considerably more laidback. The inclusion of little-known gems such as the gospelly &quot;Shine a Light&quot;, the slithery blues of &quot;The Spider &amp; the Fly&quot;, the bopping 60's soul feel of &quot;I'm Free&quot;, the country twang of &quot;Dead Flowers&quot;, &amp; the jaunty old-time blues of &quot;Sweet Virginia&quot; were strokes of genius. They're naturals at Dylan's &quot;Like a Rolling Stone&quot; (dare I say this is the definitive version??). &quot;Let It Bleed&quot; fits in nicely with the rest of the set. &quot;Wild Horses&quot; &amp; &quot;Angie&quot; were obvious choices. B00006RAKP|4.0|Little attention was paid to Elton John when he first appeared on the scene. It took a solid two years after he broke in the US for his native UK to notice him. Maybe he needed a better fashion sense to gain the attention. Anyway, this is a fine comprehensive collection of John's string of hit singles. What's amazing is how little craftsmanship and art there is in hit singles now. John in collaboration (for the most part) with long time lyricist Bernie Taupin concentrated on craftsmanship. Sure he borrowed from The Beatles, The Stones and others but he managed to craft their unique elements into his own unique sound. His most fertile period was 1970 through 1975 (by the time of Blue Moves his muse had abandoned him).<br />His work in the late 70's with Gary Osborne lacked the melodic sense and insightful (if slightly convulted and occasionally overdramatic) lyrics of Taupin. Both did far from their best work when working with others. By 21 at 33 John resumed his collaboration with Taupin (as well as still working with Osborne and others).<br /> ... His work in the 80's wasn't quite up to par to his best work. There were still many highlights and Too Low For Zero along with some of the albums after that were pretty strong. This great collection isn't definitive--it lacks a number of key album tracks and focuses on the singles (rightly so) but includes many lesser singles.<br />It's nice that Gus Dudgeon's involved and importance to Elton's early albums are finally acknowledged. He was George Martin to Elton's Beatles (or Jimmy Miller to his Stones). His best work was with Dudgeon (and his best later work was with the talented Chris Thomas as producer).<br />The rarities included here (like The Who's Ultimate Collection) aren't really rare but they're nice additions.

B00006L7XQ|3.0|This is not a great album. As a lifelong, devoted listener to the words and music of Johnny Cash, and very aware of the personal circumstances in his life, I would much prefer to have written something a bit more triumphant. But that would just be dishonest.<br />So much filler. Well-intentioned stuff that just didn't work for whatever reason - maybe the wrong song for Cash's style, the wrong arrangement, or something more elusive. \\"Bridge Over Troubled Water\\", \\"Personal Jesus\\", \\"The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face\\", \\"Danny Boy\\", \\"Desperado\\" - none of this resonates and touches the heart the way so much of the material on the previous three \\"American\\" albums does.<br />And what makes it all the more noticeable is the title cut, \\"The Man Comes Around\\". In stark contrast, this song is a monster, one of the very best (and immediately a candidate for THE best) songs Johnny Cash has ever recorded. We all think about life and death, but rarely is this abstraction so brilliantly expressed in song. \\"The Man Comes Around\\" is frightening and reassuring all at once. The book of Revelations swings open, the words and images jump from the pages and swirl around as if it were a scene from some \\"Raiders of the Lost Ark\\" movie, and the spirit is transported. One cannot listen to this piece and not be moved and changed. <br />And it is so much a Johnny Cash song. The lyric goes \\"WHEN the man comes around\\", but by dropping the \\"When\\" in titling it, Cash teases us with the double meaning. I can see him laughing to himself when he thought of it. Here is this man, practically loitering at the doorway to the next dimension, delivering with the all power and cockiness of a young king rooster. He's not saying \\"Don't write me off\\" - that is defeat in disguise. It's \\"Be careful treading in my yard, son. Looks are deceiving\\". Because they are.<br />Now, that's a tough act to follow. And for a while at least, the album hangs in there. \\"Hurt\\" is very good - moody and melodic, soft and strong. \\"Give My Love to Rose\\" is strong as well, but it's a reworking of a song done before, and turns out to be a signpost for a loss of momentum. \\"Bridge Over Troubled Water\\" is acceptable, but nothing more. One more step up for Sting's \\"Hung My Head\\", but then that's it, really. The atmosphere of foreboding and brilliance established early on is lost, and things get kind of pedestrian thereafter.<br />What this really should have been is an EP. Take the first five tracks, drop \\"Bridge\\", maybe add \\"Sam Hall\\" as a finisher, and you'd have something tight, strong, and honest.  Because, no matter how it was packaged and sold, the essential piece was \\"The Man Comes Around\\". There was no need to dress things up any further.<br />Now, that creaky old SOB is showing us that not only can he do this stuff, he IS this stuff. No time to sit and around and get cozy, John. Put another great one together, because you can, and that's what you do. We'll be waiting for you. Outside the yard, just to be on the safe side.
1573226521|5.0|Skipping the synopsis, I'll just tell you why I liked the book so much.  It seems that in the book world today we are caught up with Tom Clancy's terrorists and Anne Rice's vampires, and we have forgotten what real literature is.  Literary devices like symbolism and dramatic irony may have been lost in place of guns and blood, but these are found in plenty in Garland's masterpeice The Beach.<br />     This book can be read by the casual reader who likes tropical settings and an exciting storyline(both of which Garland utilizes expertly), or the hardcore lit buff who wants to read it and re-read it looking for subtleties and messages.  I have personally read it three times so far and I'm pleasantly suprised with a new meaning each time.  Garland will not vanish from the world of books, he will be very famous one day.
0316096199|5.0|I'm giving this book five stars as it really is a fantastic book.  The best non fiction always reads like fiction and Lucky does that and does it well.  Alice's description of the rape and aftermath are so well done you feel as though you were there in Syracuse at the time.  However, the book does have a MAJOR fault.  The ending.  I couldn't believe when I got to the ending and there was a short chapter on her heroin use following college with no real warning this was coming.  You are reading along and in the entire book I don't think any substance beyond alcohol is mentioned (as least as far as Alice's intake is concerned).  Suddenly, there in the last chapter she's discussing smoking heroin and living the life of a vagabond.  She just doesn't segue into this very well.  There's no real description of how she began, how she stopped, etc.  I felt like I was reading a different book by a different author.  Considering how much of her family she exposed, her mother's \\"flaps\\" (anxiety attacks-the poor woman was clearly under-medicated or improperly medicated), her parent's indifferent style of loving not only each other but their children; she seems to clam up about this side of herself.   It seems impossible to think that she's intentionally clamming up after vividly and explicitly describing everything else that's happened to her.  It's as though she doesn't think her substance abuse problem was connected to the fallout from the rape.  This being stated,  Alice Seebold is one author that I eagerly anticipate reading any and everything she writes.

B00005A0RI|3.0|I don't suppose there's really anything wrong with this album. The songs are really quite lovely. They are also, however, (in my opinion) mostly pretty boring. I hoped for more from an album with such an alluring title and premise (Haden's jazz with a Cuban influence), but was disappointed. For me, it lacked both diversity and spice-two things I excitedly hoped to find.<br />The only track that really seems to have much individual character is track 8, &quot;El Ciego (The Blind).&quot;  All the other tracks blend practically seamlessly together, sounding FAR too much like everything else I've ever heard of Haden's, albeit with somewhat of a Cuban influence which, at times, I didn't even particularly notice. Still, they were beautiful, regardless of their similarities.<br />Another problem I had was with the general mood of the music on the album. The title (Nocturne) and the notion of a Cuban influence was appealing to me because they somehow indicate a sort of provocative sensuality. Overall, however, I found the music generally wistful and somewhat melancholy. It was just a bit too slow, being more the music of someone drinking alone in a quiet bar than the music of a busy, exciting nightlife (Cuban or otherwise). It really even lacks the potential of the latter. Only a couple of tracks managed to supply any notion of excitement, the two most notable being &quot;Tres Palabras (Three Words)&quot; and (again) &quot;El Ciego (The Blind).&quot;<br />In short, I really enjoy Haden's work, but had hoped for a little more of something different in this album that I didn't see. It's a lovely collection of slow, wistful recordings, but if you're looking for anything electrifying, you might look somewhere else.
B00006SFBD|4.0|First off, I discovered Opeth by hearing Blackwater Park. I now own all their CDs. I know to expect a mixture of acoustic passages, clean vocals, Cookie Monster Deth Vox, and double-bass augmented power riffs galore. This album is little different with a few more glaring weak points, and therein lies my only reason for giving this CD 4 stars.<br />This CD is intended to be the first of a two disc set: the companion, titled \\"Damnation\\", is to be released next spring. Interviews with the primary songwriter, Michael Akerfeldt, would lead you to believe that this is the heavier. disc of the two. By God, is it ever heavy!  Six tracks, five over 10:00 long.<br />The first two tracks, \\"Wreath\\" and the title track, are brutal in its delivery of pounding double bass and good ol' Opethian riffage. There are a few respites in the action, but for the most part both are an assault on the senses. The last 4 minutes of the title track, however, are the same two riffs repeated over and over and over again. I think it ended up just adding time to the song and not adding to the mood like Blackwater Park's \\"Drapery Falls\\" did.<br />If you ever consider buying this album, do it for \\"A Fair Judgement\\". Although the lyrics themselves are short, base, and relatively unimaginative, the bluesy influences and guitar solo halfway through make this song great. In fact, because (or in spite of) this song is missing the Cookie Monster Deth Vox, this song makes the album Opeth. <br />The next track, \\"Absent Friends\\", is the necessary soft instrumental. Nothing really there to spark the imagination, in my opinion, but it recharges your batteries for two more barrages of Opeth metal, which \\"Master's Apprentices\\" and \\"By The Pain I See In Others\\" serve well enough. The album closes with a few bars of keyboard noodling (likely by Mr. Wilson from the band Porcupine Tree) and FX-laden 'backwards singing' of a few lines from \\"Master's Apprentices\\". The vocals themselves kinda weirded me out. Probably something to listen to at night with nothing on but a black light.<br />Why did I give this album 4 stars, even though I love Opeth to death? Because I feel that my expectations weren't quite met given previous material. Because I think this is the first real \\"formula\\" Opeth album. Because I am sure they are capable of more than one standout track on an album. Because I can immediately recommend almost every other album to listen to from this band INSTEAD of this one.<br />Don't get me wrong, this is not a bad disc at all. I would just recommend going elsewhere first if you aren't familiar with Opeth yet, preferably Blackwater Park or My Arms, Your Hearse first. For Opeth fans: this is more of the same but still recommended to add to your collection.
0312243022|5.0|THE HOURS begins with the gifted author, poet and visionary Virginia Woolf drowning herself rather than facing another period of madness. The subsequent text entwines three narrative paths: Virginia Woolf as she writes MRS DALLOWAY during the 1920s; California housewife Mrs. Laura Brown whose favorite book is MRS DALLOWAY during the 1940s; and book editor Mrs. Clarissa Vaughan, nicknamed \\"Mrs. Dalloway\\" in the 1950s. Three women, three different timeframes, all bound together in a shimmering conclusion that is destined to haunt the reader long after the last page is turned. <br />Clarissa Vaughan plans a party for her friend Richard, who has just won a major literary award for his poetry. Housewife Laura Brown struggles to find more meaning to her life than a simple existence than just as a wife and as a mother. The text brilliantly exposes their psyches, capturing the subtle nuances and flavors with a graceful pen; thereby exploring the contradictions and compromises that create our existence; deftly detailing fluidity of time and existence. <br />While mass-market readers may be a bit baffled by THE HOURS, literary scholars and classics lovers will adore it. Readers who bring a through knowledge of Virginia Woolf, a love of her novel MRS DALLOWAY, and an appreciation of the poetry of language will discover an amazing gift of beauty within this finely woven novel. Indeed, Virginia Woolf scholars will recognize the influence of ORLANDO, THE WAVES and A ROOM OF ONE'S OWN, as well as MRS DALLOWAY. In addition, admirers of the beauty of language will be stunned by Cunningham's ability to capture Woolf's voice and style in her sections, to flavor it with his own voice in the Clarissa Dalloway's sections, and then to exhibit his own unique voice and style in the Laura Brown's sections. A memorable novel to treasure, THE HOURS earns the WordWeaving Award for Excellence.

B000065U1N|3.0|I must have watched this film at least 25 or 30 times ,and came away each time shaking my head in askance as to why we  were there in the first place. The exploits of Task Force Ranger were detailed very well in the book ; the film , although very \\"heroic\\" really didn't own up to the fact that the whole operation was screwed up. Over 60% of the Rangers and Delta Force boys were either killed or wounded. That critical diatribe aside , I thought that the portrayal of the young Americans who fought the battle of Mogodishu was very good. Tom Sizemore always brings his character to life--this time LTC Danny McKnight. In fact Colonel McKnight was perhaps the most realistic senior officer involved in the battle ; he realized what a terrible risk was being taken by the senior brass to capture the warlord Mohammed Farah Aidid. <br />The combat scenes that follow the landing of the Ranger chalks are pretty realistic ; the axiom that \\"no plan survives contact with the enemy\\" , the one the brass forgot , plays out before the viewer's eyes. Those who have never served in the military cannot understand that full auto fire can really do a number on the hearing as portrayed in the movie. This film shows the enormously destructive power of modern helicopters as well as their vulnerability to small arms ground fire...<br />I guess I didn't really \\"enjoy\\" this film ; I found myself time-warped back 35 years to my time in the army , and found myself cursing the politicians who got us into this situation and the generals who did the planning(?!) for the operation.<br />As a general comment on the film , it really is a must see. However the book is a must read if you watch the film. I rated the film only 3 stars because it didn't reveal to the audience the real magnitude of the tragedy to both sides. It is , however , a suitable tribute to the soldiers who served.

B00006LPER|5.0|THE PIANO TEACHER goes places most film makers dare not tread - the dark aspects of frustrated sexuality where desire and affection cannot meet.  In brief, this is the story of the inner world of an exceptional pianist and piano teacher who lives with her mother in a 'marriage arrangement' that appears to satisfy both with its accompanying fights, jealousies, cheatings, and clingings.  This cold pianist (incomparably portrayed by the fine Isabelle Huppert) is absorbed by Schubert and Schumann and shares many of those composers' tendencies towards madness and melancholy.  Her private acting out of her sexual life includes forays into pornography video booths, drive-in movies for voyeurism, and other sadomasochistic practices that leave her frustrated in her drive to be humiliated and beaten.  Into this sad woman's life enters a sensuously handsome student (again, played with complete credibility and finesse by Benoit Magimel) and much of the film is a hard driving match between lust/desire and need/repulsion, the true approach/avoidance conflict.  The pace of the film is so correct for a story about the extended periods of ennui between moments of exhilharation that mirror the life inside a music academy.  We are treated to some wonderful Schubert, Schumann, Schonberg, and Bach that serves as the 'dialogue' during extended scenes where the piano teacher listens with her eyes and ears and dsitorted mind, reacting to the music in equal parts with the performing students.  Yes, this is a distrubing film, but it is not a grotesque film.  Director Michael Haneke manages to place this surreal sexual tragedy for us to understand just how wide the bell curve of human sexuality stretches.  An astonishingly fine film - if you are open to explore the dark interstices of the human mind without prejudice.  An added feature of an interview on the DVD with Isabelle Huppert about the character she portrays is exceptionally apropos and well filmed.

0060523794|5.0|Lou Gerstner has succeeded in writing a book which both provides valuable insights into the computer industry and the situation and success of IBM, as well as providing a roadmap for leaders seeking to effect strategic change in any industry.  He reveals that IBM was close to running out of cash in 1993 before he stepped in and kicked out the investment bankers (later pilloried as greedy suppliers of the \\"hooch for all of the wild speculative periods in our economic history\\") who were preparing to sell of IBM, a national treasure, in pieces.<br />The book is easy to read, non-technical, and laced with interesting anecdotes.  <br />Turning around IBM was one of the greatest business achievements of our time.  I have worked much of my career in companies that competed against IBM and have known many ex-IBMers.  All continue to have great respect for the people and the organization.  There is no question that IBM had, and has, some of the best people in the world.  Yet, they became unable to execute appropriate strategies quickly, losing much of their market share in the process.  <br />Lou Gerstner rejuvenated the company, a task which is rarely permanently successful in the high technology world.  Today, IBM still sells mainframes (much less expensive now, but an extension of the basic architecture introduced in 1964).  And, that technology is still at the center of the IT organizations of many of our largest companies.  Introduced later, but now long gone, are the Digital VAX, the Intel 8080, the Zilog Z80 and various computer architectures from the likes of Prime, Wang, Data General, etc.  Most have been replaced by Unix or Windows.<br />We have Lou Gerstner to thank for saving IBM.  As the book describes, he did it by focusing on the customer, eliminating useless bureaucratic processes, and, as a non-engineer, understanding the business implications of technology change better than most within IBM.  But, it was execution, focus on cash flow and profits over revenues, and constant attention to detail in strategic planning and monitoring, together with communications and leadership which saved the day for IBM.<br />The title is interesting.  Elizabeth Moss Kanter, a Harvard Business School Professor, wrote Teaching Elephants to Dance in 1989.  Gerstner refers to some of her other works late in the book, but not this one, which appears to have provided the inspiration for the title of his book.

B00006CXSS|5.0|A bonus feature included with the DVD set provides a hint at what makes this production a one-of-a-kind classic.  An actor, Ron Livingston, kept a video diary of the beginning stages of his involvement in the production.  We see him beginning to research his role of Lewis Nixon, Battalion and Regimental intelligence officer by reading Stephen Ambrose histories and 1940's field manuals.  He meets Lewis Nixon's widow and pores over photos of the man he's playing.  We see him awed by a telephone call with the REAL commander of Easy Company, Dick Winters,in which he promises to do his best in acting the part of Winters' lifelong friend. <br />THAT's part of what makes this production special.  The writers did additional research for each episode, in many cases interviewing the surviving members or family of Easy Company.  The actors did the same, in many cases calling from the set to run a line reading by the vet they were playing.  The Easy family members speak fondly of \\"our actor,\\" the one who played their vet.  All of that bonding and commitment to getting it right comes through on the screen.  <br />This is an off-the-charts production that repays repeated viewings.  I cannot speak of it too highly.

B00006V9A0|5.0|Kurt does not live.  Nirvana did not change the world. B00006M183|5.0|Riot Act is Pearl Jam's strongest, most consistent effort since 1996's No Code.  The band sounds more confident and more daring than either 1998's Yield or 2000's Binaural, though each of those releases contained major leaps and highlights.<br />What sets Riot Act apart is the subtle quirkiness and power hiding in every song.  It's a difficult album to get used to--and you won't find yourself humming along to many of the songs until around the 4th or 5th listen. There's a lack of traditional rock &quot;hooks&quot; that many rock radio listeners might find disconcerting.<br />But with repeated listenings, patience, and open-mindedness, the brilliance and fun of Riot Act is revealed.  Odd time signatures and chord progressions abound, as in Cameron's powerful &quot;Cropduster,&quot; and Ament's strange, amelodic &quot;helphelp.&quot; Yet there are moments of sheer beauty and delicacy, as in Vedder's &quot;Thumbing My Way,&quot; and the nicotine whiskey closer &quot;All Or None,&quot; which is destined to be a classic in the Pearl Jam canon.<br />Much will be made of the political content of such songs as &quot;Bushleaguer&quot; and &quot;Green Disease,&quot; which is at turns humorous, passionate, and ahem, infectious--but none of which would mean anything if it weren't couched in the only musical setting worth listening to in mainstream rock music.<br />Whether or not the hype dies down, Riot Act will be one of the best rock releases of the year, and is recommended along with the import single for &quot;I Am Mine,&quot; which includes two previously unreleased b-sides, &quot;Down&quot; and &quot;Undone,&quot; which are well worth the price.

B000001ESP|5.0|When I was in college, a guy down the hall from me who owned a massive high-powered stereo system got into the habit of playing \\"Moving Pictures\\" every day. Daily at around 3:00 in the afternoon, when I returned from my calculus class, I would hear Neil tapping out the Morse Code letters \\"Y-Y-Z\\" twice on his high-hat, followed by incredibly loud power chords playing the same pattern.<br />After about a month of this, the floor pothead politely knocked on the Rush fan's door and said, in a blurry-sounding voice, \\"Dude, like, Moving Pictures is a great album and all, man, but, like, do you HAVE to play it every single day?\\"<br />Well, yes, he did. Because Moving Pictures could be the best rock album ever recorded. Beatles and Floyd and Stones and Zep fans may disagree, but I truly believe one would be hard-pressed to find a more consistent collection of solid tunes ever made.<br />In Paris is housed the Standard Meter -- a bar of metal exactly a meter long, encased in a special inert gas to prevent expansion or contraction. If there were to be a Standard Rush Album kept in Toronto under a glass dome, used as the measure against which all other Rush albums were to be gauged, this would be it.<br />The musicianship is uniformly tight, the Three Men From Willowdale meshing together like teeth on a zipper. Neil's drumbeats are crisp and staccato, Geddy's bass grumbles and roars like a dragon, and Alex reaches stratospheric heights like never before.<br />Put on Moving Pictures, and you're immediately a teenager again, not entirely satisfied with hair-metal, definitely not into teeny-pop, brooding, sensitive, captured by the group's musical depths, enraptured by Neil's intellectual lyrics.<br />Nothing more need be said -- and can be said.
B00003CX9E|5.0|Citizen Kane generally is considered the greatest film ever made.  It has top numerous lists (including AFI's Top 100 American Films) and is revered by practically every movie critic.  While some film has to rank number one, and Citizen Kane deserves the title as much as any film, actually watching the film is a bit of a letdown.  That is not to deny the film's greatness.  Orson Welles directed, co-wrote and stars in the film and he set the standard for the likes of Woody Allen and Spike Lee to command the three major components of a movie.  No one else reached the levels of greatness that Mr. Welles reached with Kane.  His acting is brilliant, the screenplay is sharp and his directing is first rate.  The fact that he only won an Oscar for the screenplay and the film was a commercial bomb shows that the Academy and film going public weren't ready to accept this progressive film and how he was ahead of his time.  The actors in the film were apart of Mr. Welles' Mercury Players and they all (especially Joseph Cotton) give strong turns.  Going back to my point about the film being a bit of a letdown, I mean with all the praise and superlatives that are heaped on the Citizen Kane, the film has set such an impossible buildup, it may not meet the modern film fan's expectations.  The bonus disk is worthy of a separate release itself.  It contains the documentary, The Battle Over Citizen Kane, which itself was nominated for an Oscar, that is one of the better documentaries about Hollywood that has been produced.  Orson Welles was a true movie visionary, but despite the fact that he would go on to create many first rate films, he was never able to duplicate the greatness of Citizen Kane.

B00005QW5X|5.0|The first time I saw this DVD, I had borrowed it from a friend. Rocky Horror 2? Sure, I'll check it out. I now realize that comparing Hedwig to Rocky Horror is like comparing Goodfellas to Cabin Boy. The first thing I noticed was how the movie drew me in, from the fantastic opening number to the final credits. I had such a good time. But actually realizing how great the film is, catching the little details, didn't start until the second viewing. I'm now on viewing number five and I'm still finding nuggets of brilliance -- I just noticed something interesting about Hedwig's tattoo, which appears in one of the first and last scenes (pay close attention). The songs are all incredible, the performances uniformly sublime. The ambient noise throughout is surprisingly well done; in the restaurant scenes you can barely hear people ordering chicken fingers, with glasses breaking at extremely humorous moments. The editing -- everyone has the perfect expression in every shot (I love the unwitting audience members). The early scene of Yitzhak trying on the wig carries a Shakespearean depth and import. Nothing in this film is tossed in at random; everything has a significance and you could write papers unpacking its richness. The theme of tomatoes being thrown and subsequently eaten is an interesting recurring thread not many people pick up on. This is artwork of the highest calibre. Yeah, if you're uptight about gender and sexuality, the film may trouble you. But watch with an open mind and the universal themes will touch you. You will walk away a changed person.

B00006SFBD|5.0|Opeth, not merely music but rather a listening experience.  With the release of their sixth album, Deliverence the band delves more deeply into their death metal roots.  All the brutality of Ackerfeldt's grunts, growls, and screams are present as are a plethera of melodic rythym and lead guitars.  Compared to Orchid, Still Life, and Blackwater Park (I havn't heard My Arms or Morningrise) this album has much much much more of a death metal feel to it; there are even a series of more grindy riffs not common in the guitar-driven and classic rock oriented Sweedish death metal scene.  This is not a bad thing and indeed it makes the album stand out as different.  The only downfall of the album in my opinion is the fact that the acoustic passages which on Orchid have an enchanting flow to them that merges the music together perfectly, are absent on deliverence.  Not totally absent as acoustics make up a large part of the Opeth sound; they are however boring and redundant on Deliverance and seem to lack the emotion of the accoustics heard on Orchid or Still Life.  All in all, this is still Opeth and this album is a must have for all Opeth fans.

B00006RAKP|2.0|When record labels usually release Greatest Hits collections, there is most of the time, a miss that comes within the collections. That case came exactly right here with the music of Elton John. Although he has been making music for more than 30 years, not even all of his songs can come into a full collection.<br />The 2002 Greatest Hits 1970-2002, compiles over 30 of Elton's biggest songs in his entire career, including Your Song, Sorry Seems To Be the Hardest Word, and I'm Still Standing. Although it seems to be the maximum of massive hits for Elton John, I was truly surprised, because there were at least a dozen of Elton's hit songs that didn't even make the collection like Candle In The Wind 1997, The Last Song, Empty Garden, Club At The End Of The Street, and Someday Out Of The Blue. It seems to be a sad state of affairs when record labels can't even do it right.<br />Unfortunately, this collection isn't exactly a good collection of Elton John's career. You're better off getting the re-released box set, To Be Continued..., or expecting a seperate Greatest Hits collection of Elton John's music from the 1990's and beyond.

Overall, this album isn't amazing like Vs. or Vitalogy, but it's still a very good one. I recommend this for any Pearl Jam fan, but if you're just getting into them, i'd  recommend buying Vs. or Ten first.

B00005JKCH|4.0|Spider-Man is not a perfect movie.  But it does so many important things right that it can be forgiven for its weaker points.  Most importantly, it is a fun, kinetic movie that doesn't let up.<br />The most successful element of Spider-Man is its inspired choices in personnel.  Director Sam Raimi brings his manic visualization skills to the film, making Spidey's famous &quot;webswinging&quot; as exciting as they can be, without undue showing off.  And the casting is simply brilliant.  Tobey Maguire was made for this role.  Not only does he nail the physical elements (his transformation from thin bookworm to stringily muscular acrobat, the shyness and awkwardness), but he is especially marvellous at expressing Spidey's chatty, self-deprecatory sense of humour.  The best performance of his career so far.  Kirsten Dunst was a terrific choice for Mary Jane -- while she is sometimes saddled with cheesy scenes (the final scene at the cemetary being especially disappointing), Dunst is never less than lovable.  And her kiss in the rain with an upside-down Spider-Man is probably the sexiest moment in movies this year!  Willem Dafoe deserves more screen time as Green Goblin; Dafoe is more than good enough as an actor to craft a character akin to The Joker in Tim Burton's Batman, but the script, by red-hot screenwriter David Koepp (Mission:  Impossible, The Panic Room) doesn't really allow him to explore the character's depths.  That appears to be a conscious chioce on Koepp and Raimi's part to keep the focus squarely on Peter Parker/Spider-Man, so it's forgiveable.  The one weak link is James Franco (City by the Sea), who plays Peter's best friend completely at face value, seemingly addicted to a furrowed-eyebrow expression to try to show internal turmoil but falling flat on his face.<br />The comedic elements are delightful; the origins of Spider-Man's name is a hoot, as are his interactions with Mary Jane and the Daily Bugle.  The overall sense of fun is infectious, and thestory moves along briskly enough that there are never any dull moments.<br />A great movie for sheer entertainment.

B00006NSZ5|5.0|First of all, DJ ENC, a soundtrack is provided as a musical score of what is occurring in the movie.   In most cases, instead of performing songs that are strictly for the movie, a cast of artists are assembled to contribute songs to the project.   In this case, the system works for the most part.  Eminem fans will be satisfied since Eminem is featured on 6 tracks, if you have the deluxe limited edition.  \\"Lose Yourself\\", the soundtrack's lead single is clearly the best song on the CD as Eminem leaves the comedy alone and actually makes a dead serious track.  He reflects on the movie's lead character, Jimmy Smith Jr. aka Bunny Rabbit, and he pours his heart and soul into the song.   The title track goes through Rabbit's trials and tribulations that he has to deal with in the movie with his family life, his job and his personal struggles.   On \\"Rabbit Run\\", Eminem raps one continuous verse without any kind of hook and definitely wins with this format.    It feels like Rabbit is able to release his rage in one verse and Eminem fans will love this song.   On the deluxe limited edition song with Em, \\"Stimulate\\", seems as if it was left off of \\"The Eminem Show\\".   While it may be a winner with diehard Eminem fans, it doesn't break any new ground for him.    Eminem is featured on  D 12's song, \\"Rap Game\\", where he even goes as far as rapping in Pig latin and on one of the best songs on the soundtrack, \\"Love Me\\" featuring Obie Trice and 50 Cent.   Eminem uses a Bob James sample and all three rappers deliver a decent performance.   Since Obie Trice and 50 Cent are now signed to Shady Records, you would expect that from them.  50 Cent even goes as far as cracking jokes on Lil Kim, Lauryn Hill, D'Angelo, Ashanti and Charli Baltimore.   Anyone that is a fan of 50's underground cuts will enjoy this song.   He also has two solo cuts on 8 Mile, \\"Wanksta\\" and \\"Places To Go\\".   \\"Wanksta\\" will sound familiar to 50 Cent fans if they follow the mixed CD circuit and the song is the 1stsingle to his full length solo CD, \\"Get Rich Or Die Trying\\".   Both songs will definitely create enough of a buzz until the CD drops.   Although, Obie Trice has been featured on the D 12 CD and on Eminem's \\"Drips\\" from \\"The Eminem Show\\", I would still say 50 Cent has more potential.   However, Obie doesn't disappoint on his solo cut \\"Adrenaline Rush\\" and on his 1st single \\"Rap Name\\", which is featured on the deluxe limited edition CD.   While this CD does seem like a Shady Records promotional soundtrack, other rappers make quality contribuions as well.   It seems like Nas has some more words for Jay Z on his contribution for 8 Mile, \\"U Wanna Be Me\\".   While he is currently seeking an end to the beef, it seems as if he had other things on his mind while he was performing this track.   However, this track is classic Nasty Nas as he gears his fans up for his new CD \\"God's Son\\" which will be released on December 17th.   Coincidentally,  Jay Z is featured on the same soundtrack.   Hmmmm, I guess Lil Kim was right when she said \\"Money Talks, BS walks...\\".   It seems as if Jay Z and Freeway are more worried about promoting their new releases on \\"8 Miles And Running\\" but Jay Z represents as he always does and Freeway will have even more fans waiting for his frequently delayed solo release.   Xzibit shows up with the Denaun Porter produced \\"Spit Shine\\".   Porter also produced Xzibit's first single from his latest release, \\"Man Vs Machine\\", \\"Multiply\\".   Other artists making contributions are Gang Starr, Rakim, and Macy Gray, yes that's right, Macy Gray.  Her song isn't that bad but it is definitely out of place.   Taryn Manning makes an outstanding contribution with \\"Wasting My Time\\".   Although, this slow jam is definitely out of place, if she gets with the right people, this singer will have a nice future on her hands.   Overall, I would recommend 8 Mile to anyone who is an Eminem fan.   Although 50 Cent and Obie Trice make good performances, many people may see this as aShady Records soundtrack and not a soundtrack for 8 Mile.   <br />James' Top 5<br />1) Lose Yourself- Eminem<BR>2) Love Me- Eminem, 50 Cent & Obie Trice<BR>3) Wanksta- 50 Cent<BR>4) U Wanna Be Me- Nas<BR>5) Places To Go- 50 Cent

B000056K04|4.0|Despite years of critical acclaim and the development of a devoted fan base, the Dave Matthews Band still managed to stay right on the edge of mainstream popularity.  Aside from a few singles from their first three albums, most of their music is not 'radio friendly'.  It plays better when the full album is listened to, and is quite spectacular in concert.  <BR><BR>   Achieving mainstream success is not the brass ring every band is striving for, though.  Mainstream music doesn't exactly mean good music.  A lot of what passes as mainstream music is prefabricated, over-produced pop garbage.  In many instances, bands that developed a strong following outside of the mainstream are perceived as 'sellouts' by that loyal fan base once they make music in that area.  In this case, however, the Dave Matthews Band has accomplished a rare balancing act.  With the help of a new producer, they assembled an album of more polished, radio-friendly songs without sacrificing their musical soul in the process.  \\"Everyday\\" is an excellent album.  It will please the die-hard Dave fans while also being able to win new converts to the loyal fan base.  <BR><BR>   Ironically, the title song on this album is actually the worst thing about it.  The song \\"Everyday\\" is a very slow, plodding, boring tune that calls to mind some of the bands less successful attempts to keep a diverse range of music.  Aside from that song, though, the rest of the album is simply a listener's delight.  The odd number tracks on the first half of the album are the best of the bunch.  \\"I Did It\\" has that fast, fun sound it that makes it sound like \\"Too Much\\" off the \\"Crash\\" album.  \\"The Space Between\\" is an absolutely amazing song where the Dave Matthews Band is able to slow the music down, but still captures a wealth of emotion that really grabs the listener.  It's probably the band's best slow song this side of \\"Crash In To Me\\" (also off the \\"Crash\\" album).  \\"So Right\\" and \\"What You Are\\" keep the musical juices flowing with good tunes that are just fun to listen to.  When it is all said and done, this is probably the most accomplished album produced so far by the Dave Matthews Band.

B00004TEUX|5.0|It is little known that the Swiss conductor Peter Maag originally set out to be a concert pianist, his mentor in this regard being the great Swiss/French pianist Alfred Cortot (you can hear Cortot's sense of colour and spaciousness echoed in Maag's conducting, too). One of the greatest and most underrated of conductors, Peter Maag's reputation rests largely (despite his prolific recorded output for small, obscure labels) on a handful of recordings made for Decca in the '50s and '60s: Mozart concertos with Barry Tuckwell (horn) and Gervase de Peyer (clarinet), the \\"Prague\\" and 32nd symphonies, Serenata Notturna and the Notturno for four orchestras. However, it is his Mendelssohn: the \\"Scotch\\" symphony, the Hebrides Overture and the music for \\"A Midsummer Night's Dream\\" which has set the standard by which other performances to this day are judged....In this Maag was assisted by the magnificent production/engineering of Ray Minshull/Kenneth Wilkinson (\\"Scotch\\" symphony) and James Walker/Cyril Windebank (AMSND), the excellent state of the LSO at the time and, often overlooked, the unbelievably beautiful acoustics of the Methodist Kingsway Hall in London in which Decca's finest sound was achieved (it is now, sadly, unavailable for recording-it should be on the National Trusts's list for preservation as a recording space!). I don't think that this release will ever be surpassed. Buy it and revel in the artistry of Peter Maag and the LSO, as well as the extraordinary recorded sound of the Kingsway Hall, and Decca's marvellous FFRR recording. You won't be disappointed. One of the most sublime moments is the unforgotten Jennifer Vyvyan's singing in \\"You Spotted Snakes\\" - simply unsurpassable. The only regret is that the time available to the current cd medium is not sufficient to include Maag's unforgettable \\"Fingal's Cave\\" (although that WAS issued on cd in 1995 along with the \\"Scotch\\" Symphony and parts of the AMSND in Decca's series \\"The Classic Sound\\", which has now beensuperceded by \\"Legends\\"). If you love Mendelssohn, you can't remain without this release - it's simply, for a host of reasons, the best that's ever been (or likely to be) recorded.

B00006M183|4.0|I'll be the first one to admit that I was concerned about Riot Act.  While I'd been disappointed a little by previous efforts, their last, Binural, was perhaps the most disappointing Pearl Jam release.  I wasn't expecting another Ten but I was anticipating something better than their last effort.  And I got it.  Clearly, Pearl Jam is a band that's moved past the era of 90's grunge that gave birth to them and we shouldn't expect them to retreat anytime soon.  <br />Riot Act showcases the stripped-down sound they began experimenting with on Vitalogy and combines the best elements of No Code, Yield and Binural. B00006CXSS|5.0|Saving Private Ryan started a genre of WWII films whereby achieving total accuracy in both the human and military aspects of warfare was the underlying goal of the whole production.  The acting is superb; character development is very well done. Many have already raved about this series, and I could rave on about it too, it is just great, but the one area I want to expound on is the historical accuracy of this film series.  The accuracy of the battle scenes is truly fantastic, whereby the German tanks, light field howitzers and self-propelled guns are either real in some scenes but in most cases, replicated with exacting detail that would fool only the most observant WWII armor expert.  Let's face it, there are not many Tiger Is or JagdPanthers (tank destroyer) left in running condition if any at all, so it is left up to the creativity of those tasked with the production of these films to product a convincing facsimile.  In the case of the Tiger I heavy tanks, the same ones used in Private Ryan were used which were mock-ups on-top of a Russian T-34 chassis. Again, they really pulled it off, so much better than the desert-sand painted American Patton tanks serving under Field Marshall Erwin Rommel in the movie Patton (1970).  The uniforms, equipment, small arms, and sets are very accurate, and really do an effective job of transporting the viewer back to the 1944-1945 ETO.<br />This is a great series, and a very nicely done DVD collection, too bad you can't give it 10 stars because I would...
B00005LQ04|4.0|This creepy thriller is undoubtedly one of the better horror films to come out of the '70s. Argento found the perfect heroine in Jessica Harper, who plays the role of an emotionally detached American at a German ballet school. The emotional detachment that she portrays in her character adds significantly to the mood of the film. Argento also uses color for setting mood brillianty, much in the same style as Kubrik, though not with quite with the subtleness that Kubrik used color in his films. The acting of the rest of the cast is satisfactory at best, with the exception of the first two victims who shouldn't have been given any dialogue in the film. 3/5 stars for low grade acting and poor special effects. But mood, atmosphere, and suspense, the foundation of any good horror, get a solid 5/5 stars.
B00006LLLN|4.0|They have won countless music awards, released more than nine CDs, and have been hailed as some of the best musicians in the business.  But in their 15 years together, Alison Krauss and Union Station have never released a live album. . . until now.<br /><br />  On Nov. 5, bluegrass's brightest shining stars unveiled their first attempt at a live recording.  Titled simply Live, the two disc set was recorded in Louisville, KY, during last spring's New Favorite tour.  The focus of Live is mostly on the group's last two albums, New Favorite and the Grammy award winning Forget About It, with old favorites mixed in.  From the traditional flavored \\"Every Time You Say Goodbye\\" to the haunting \\"Broadway\\" to Krauss's mainstream hit \\"When You Say Nothing At All,\\" the album is effective not only in highlighting the band's recent work, but introducing fans to classic recordings as well.  Two of the group's contributions to the O Brother Where Art Thou soundtrack, \\"Down to the River to Pray\\" and the acclaimed \\"I Am A Man of Constant Sorrow\\" are also featured.  One of the most unique aspects of Live is the album's ability to portray the magic and intimacy of a Krauss performance.  Krauss's endearing introductions to songs, the humorous comments made by guitarist Dan Tyminski, and the ecstatic reactions of the audience perfectly capture the experience of the concert, showing listeners that seeing the band live is unforgettable.<br /><br />  Since the group's formation in the mid-1980s, Alison Krauss and Union Station have established a place for themselves as skilled, incomparable musicians, and there is no doubt that Live will become yet another addition to their accomplishments.  If you love musicians who possess nothing but talent and skill, the group's first live album is a must for your music library.

The album is multi-faceted, diverse in several styles for your listening pleasure.<BR><br /><br /> The opening track shows Opeth's roots. If you like hard rock, and beautiful rock songs with soul, you could not possibly go wrong with Opeth's 'Blackwater Park'.<BR>

B00006IR5S|2.0|&quot;Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets&quot; represents the second big disappointment from film composer extraordinaire John Williams in 2002, the first being his lackluster, uninspiring score for &quot;Star Wars: Episode II.&quot;<br />The &quot;Chamber of Secrets&quot; score has little to say that wasn't already said in &quot;The Sorcerer's Stone.&quot; All of the themes from the previous film appear, and they are drilled into our heads over and over and over again on this new album. The only new theme to speak of is for Fawkes the Phoenix, and it is a rather unmemorable one at that.<br />Then there's this business of the score being &quot;adapted and conducted by William Ross,&quot; yet the album liner notes insist that John Williams composed the music. Why does this sound suspiciously like they're crediting Williams for his &quot;Sorcerer's Stone&quot; score here, and William Ross is responsible for what little new material there is to hear? Either way, Williams has not delivered.<br />Is John Williams finally tired of scoring overblown fantasy films? It certainly seems that way. He didn't even bother to write new music for the spectacular arena battle at the end of &quot;Episode II&quot; -- the film just recycled cues right out of &quot;Episode I.&quot; Sure, his &quot;Minority Report&quot; score was an interesting switch for Williams, but can you remember anything about it other than it was &quot;different&quot;? I can't.<br />After the double disappointment of &quot;Potter&quot; and &quot;Episode II,&quot; Williams can no longer be considered the premier film composer; perhaps that title belongs to Thomas Newman, Hans Zimmer or Howard Shore nowadays.

B000002505|5.0|At first you would think this collaboration would prove problematical. Fusioneer-Jazz guitarist meets Latin/Rock guitarist. Not only does it work but it works brilliantly. A departure in a sense for both. Backed by stellar musicians including Billy Cobham and Larry Young. They explore a series of complex pieces in perfect cohesion. They play with great sensitivity and are always listening. This one stands  as one of his(Carlos Santana's) true masterpieces along with \\"Caravanserai\\" and \\"<br />Welcome\\". This one left you hoping for a sequel. Unfortunately it did not come making this release so much more special in the scheme of things. They brought out the best in one another. Carlos' playing is crisp and sharp without sacrifice to his expressiveness. The usually very fleet fingered John McLaughlin (then known as Mahavishnu) was especially empassioned. This album reminds me of how that particular time was so glorious in music. There was an explosion of style and new directions that was more based in musicality than in technology as is the case today. Bravo!
